PART 1. GENERAL
2.06.101: PURPOSE:
These rules of order and procedures are designed and adopted for the purpose of
providing guidance and direction to the members of the city council, planning
commission and sensitive lands committee in public meetings. (Ord. 2011-10,
2011)
2.06.102: BASIC PRINCIPLES:
   (1)   State Law Controls: If anything herein is in conflict with state law,
state law shall govern and control.
   (2)   Public Body: As used herein, the term "public body" shall refer to the
city council, the planning commission or the sensitive lands committee.
   (3)   Chair: As used herein, the term "chair" shall refer to either the
mayor or the person elected by the planning commission or sensitive lands
committee to act as chair.
   (4)   Vice Chair: As used herein, the term "vice chair" shall refer to the
person elected by the public body as either the mayor pro tem or vice chair.
   (5)   Equality Of Members: As the public body conducts its affairs in
accordance with these rules, each member has the same rights, privileges and
duties as any other member.
   (6)   Freedom Of Discussion: Members have the right to be heard and to hear
what others have to say about a motion before voting.
   (7)   Member Right To Know: Members have a right at all times to know the
immediate pending motion and have it restated prior to any vote.
   (8)   Meeting Properly Called: The public body may take official action only
in meetings properly called and with a quorum of members present.
   (9)   Actions Must Be Lawful: Actions taken by the public body must be in
accord with applicable city, state and federal law, including, but not limited
to, the Utah open and public meetings act. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
PART 2. DUTIES OF CHAIR AND VICE CHAIR
2.06.201: DUTIES OF CHAIR:
The chair, or in the chair's absence the vice chair, shall be in charge of all
proceedings before the public body, and shall take such actions as necessary to
preserve order and the integrity of all proceedings before the public body. The
chair's duties are as follows:
   (1)   Call the public body to order on the day and the hour scheduled and
proceed with the order of business.
   (2)   Announce the business before the public body in the order in which it
is to be acted upon.
   (3)   Receive and submit, all motions and propositions presented by the
members of the public body.
   (4)   Put to vote all questions which are properly moved, or which
necessarily arise in the course of proceedings, and to announce the results of
motions.
   (5)   Inform the public body, when necessary, on any point of order or
practice. In the course of discharge of this duty, the chair shall have the
right to call upon legal counsel for advice.
   (6)   Authenticate by signature, when necessary, or when directed by the
public body, all of the acts, findings and orders, and proceedings of the
public body.
   (7)   Maintain order at the meetings of the public body.
   (8)   Move the agenda along, hold down redundancy by limiting time allowed
for comments if necessary, set guidelines for public input, and reference
handouts and procedures during meetings.
   (9)   Recognize speakers and members prior to receiving comments and
presentations.
   (10)   Because the chair conducts the meeting, it is common courtesy for the
chair to take a less active role than other members in debates and discussions.
This does not mean that the chair should not participate; rather, the chair
should strive to be the last to speak at the discussion and debate stage.
   (11)   Should not make or second a motion unless he/she is convinced that no
other member will do so. In no event may the mayor make or second a motion.
(Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.202: DUTIES OF VICE CHAIR:
The vice chair, during the absence of the chair, shall have and perform all of
the duties and functions of the chair. In the event both the chair and vice
chair are absent from the meeting, then those members present shall elect one
of the members present to act as chair for that meeting by majority vote. (Ord.
2011-10, 2011)
PART 3. MEETINGS
2.06.301: MEETING SCHEDULE:
The public body shall establish its regular meeting schedule in December of
each year for the following calendar year. Special meetings may be requested by
a majority vote of the public body, or pursuant to section 10-3-502 of the Utah
code for the city council. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.302: AGENDA SETTING PROCEDURES:
   (1)   An item may be placed on the agenda by the mayor, city manager, or at
the request of at least two (2) members.
   (2)   Generally, the deadline for requesting placement of an application on
any public body agenda shall be at five o'clock (5:00) P.M., fifteen (15) days
prior to the public body meetings, to allow appropriate time for notifications
and staff review. Exceptions to the general deadline of fifteen (15) days prior
to the public body meeting may occur, provided there is sufficient time left to
comply with the open and public meetings act.
   (3)   The city manager shall review and approve all matters to be placed on
the agenda to assure adequate information and time is available for the public
body's consideration and decision.
   (4)   The city recorder or a deputy city recorder shall be responsible for
scheduling all public hearings for the public body and shall be responsible for
giving all required notices for meetings and public hearings for the public
body. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.303: ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS:
Every member of the public body shall attend the meetings of the public body,
unless duly excused. Any member desiring to be excused shall notify the city
recorder, who shall inform the chair of the member's planned absence. The
foregoing notwithstanding, however, state law provides that the legislative
body of a municipality may compel the attendance of its own members at its
meetings and provide penalties it considers necessary for the failure to comply
with an exercise of the authority to compel attendance. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.304: QUORUM DEFINED:
Three (3) members of the public body shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business. Except in cases where the mayor is the chair, the
chair shall be included for purposes of establishing a quorum and shall act as
a voting member of the public body. If less than a quorum is present at a
meeting, said meeting shall be canceled or rescheduled to the public body's
next available meeting and appropriate notices given. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.305: MINIMUM VOTE REQUIRED:
All actions of the public body shall require the vote of at least three (3)
members, with mayoral vote as authorized by statute. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.306: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
The public body shall conduct its proceedings consistent with the provisions of
Utah law relating to cities. The chair of the public body shall rule on all
matters of procedure with fundamental fairness. The chair may be reversed on
matters of procedure by majority vote of the public body members present and
not disqualified. Any formal action of the public body shall be initiated by a
motion and shall be seconded prior to a vote of the membership. Voting shall be
by verbal vote; the chair, but not the mayor except in cases of a tie vote,
shall vote last if a roll call vote. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.307: ORDER OF BUSINESS FOR PUBLIC HEARINGS:
The following procedure will normally be observed for public hearings; however,
it may be rearranged by the chair for individual items if necessary for the
expeditious conduct of business:
   (1)   The chair shall introduce the item.
   (2)   Staff shall present its report and recommendations.
   (3)   The applicant or petitioner shall be invited to outline the nature of
the request and present supporting evidence if the applicant or petitioner
desires to do so.
   (4)   The chair shall open the public hearing. The chair, without objection
by members of the public body, may impose time limits for comment to facilitate
the business of the public body.
   (5)   The chair shall close the public hearing.
   (6)   The chair shall allow the applicant or petitioner to address issues
raised by the public comment.
   (7)   The chair shall allow members of the public body to discuss the matter
and ask questions of the applicant or petitioner.
   (8)   The chair shall call for a motion by the public body on the
application or petition. If a substantial amount of public comment was
received, the chair may entertain a motion to continue the matter to allow
members to review the public comment.
   (9)   If the motion is seconded, a vote must be taken by the public body.
(Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.308: ORDER OF BUSINESS FOR REGULAR MEETINGS:
The following procedure will normally be observed for all meetings of the
public body; however, it may be rearranged by the chair for individual items if
necessary for the expeditious conduct of business:
   (1)   The chair shall introduce the agenda item.
   (2)   Staff shall present its report and recommendations.
   (3)   The chair shall allow members of the public body to discuss the matter
and ask questions of staff.
   (4)   The chair may call for a motion by the public body on the agenda item.
   (5)   If the motion is seconded, a vote must be taken by the public body.
(Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.309: MOTIONS:
   (1)   Any member may make or second a motion.
   (2)   Motions should state findings for approval or denial within the
motion.
   (3)   The motion may refer to the staff report for the detail of the
findings of fact and conditions for approval if the author of the motion finds
them acceptable.
   (4)   Motions may be repeated for clarification following discussion and
prior to the vote at the request of any member.
   (5)   Members may request legal advice from the city attorney in the
preparations, discussion and deliberation of motions.
   (6)   Up to two (2) motions may be on the floor simultaneously. (Ord. 2011-
10, 2011)
2.06.310: SECOND REQUIRED:
Any motion of the public body that fails to be seconded shall be deemed
defeated. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.311: WITHDRAWING A MOTION:
After a motion is made, it may be withdrawn by the author of the motion any
time prior to the vote. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.312: MOTION TO AMEND:
When a motion is pending before the public body, any member may move to amend
the original motion any time prior to the vote. The motion to amend must be
germane to the initial motion and not the same as a negative vote on the
initial motion. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.313: MOTION TO TABLE:
A motion to table an agenda item for further study should be accompanied by
specific reasons for continuing the matter. Whenever possible, a specific date
to rehear the matter should be scheduled. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.314: VOTING ON MULTIPLE MOTIONS:
When two (2) motions are on the floor at the same time, the first vote should
be on the last motion made. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.315: MOTION TO RECESS:
A motion shall be made to break for a specific purpose while also stipulating a
specific time to reconvene the meeting. The time to reconvene must be during
the same day as the meeting in which the motion to recess was made. No motion
to reconvene shall be necessary. The foregoing notwithstanding, however, the
chair may declare an immediate recess in the event of any behavior that is
disruptive to the public meeting or that raises concern for public safety.
(Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.316: MOTION TO ADJOURN:
A motion to adjourn the meeting shall be made at the end of each public
meeting. A second followed by a vote is also required on a motion to adjourn.
(Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.317: DEBATE, INTERRUPTIONS, AND QUESTIONS:
No member of the public body shall interrupt or question another member in
debate without obtaining the acknowledgment of the chair. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.318: VOTING:
   (1)   Changing A Vote: No member shall be permitted to change his/her vote
after the chair announces the decision, except when properly reconsidering an
agenda item.
   (2)   Abstention: Any member may abstain from voting. However, an abstention
shall be the equivalent of a no vote.
   (3)   Roll Call Vote: State law provides that a roll call vote shall be
taken and recorded for all ordinances, resolutions, and any action which would
create a liability against the city and in any other case at the request of any
member of the city council by a "yes" or "no" vote. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.319: RULES OF ORDER:
In accordance with these rules and procedures, the chair shall decide all
points of procedure and order, unless otherwise directed by a majority vote of
the members in attendance. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.320: SUSPENSION OR ALTERATION OF RULES:
No standing rules of the public body shall be altered, amended, suspended or
rescinded without the vote of a majority of all the members of the public body.
(Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.321: WORK MEETINGS AND/OR FIELD TRIPS:
Work meetings and/or field trips of the public body may be held if found
necessary. Notice of the work meeting and/or field trip shall be in accordance
with city and state law. The public shall be allowed at field trip sites but
encouraged to present their case at the public body's meeting, not during the
field trip. Field trips shall be for the purpose of gathering information, not
for discussing decisions. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.322: CANCELLATION:
If no business is scheduled before the public body, or if it is apparent that a
quorum of the public body will not be available, any meeting may be canceled by
the chair by giving notice to all members. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
PART 4. RECONSIDERATION
2.06.401: GROUNDS FOR RECONSIDERATION:
   (1)   Basis For Reconsideration: A proper request for reconsideration shall
be based on one or more of the following:
      (a)   The prior decision was arbitrary, capricious or otherwise illegal;
      (b)   There was some material irregularity in the proceedings when the
matter was previously voted on by the public body that makes the previous
decision improper; or
      (c)   Newly discovered evidence that is material to persons adversely
affected by the original decision that was not or could not, with reasonable
diligence, have been discovered and produced at the meeting when the matter was
previously voted on by the public body.
   (2)   Procedure:
      (a)   During the meeting in which an agenda item has been voted on, the
public body may reopen the matter by simple majority vote and reconsider their
decision. The request to reconsider the matter must be made by a member who
voted with the majority.
      (b)   After adjournment of the meeting in which an agenda item was voted
upon, reconsideration must adhere to the following, except for legislative
matters which may be reconsidered by the city council at any time:
   (i) Only voting members of the public body may request reconsideration of an
agenda item which has been voted on by the public body.
   (ii) The request for reconsideration must be made by a member who voted with
the majority when the matter was previously voted on by the public body.
   (iii) The request for reconsideration shall be transmitted in writing to the
chair within thirty (30) days following the meeting the item was previously
voted on.
   (iv) At the next regularly scheduled meeting of the public body following
the chair's receipt of a proper request for reconsideration, under the agenda
item entitled "items to be placed on future agendas", the public body will
decide whether to reconsider the item on a future agenda. A majority vote in
favor of reconsideration will place the item on a future regularly scheduled
agenda of the public body. Failure to receive a majority vote will halt the
reconsideration process.
   (v) Items approved for reconsideration shall be placed on the next regularly
scheduled meeting agenda of the public body unless the public body specifically
votes to set a different schedule for reconsidering the matter. All affected
parties who appeared at and/or participated in the meeting at which the matter
was previously voted on shall be mailed written notice by the city recorder of
the date of reconsideration. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
PART 5. CONDUCT OF MEMBERS
2.06.501: CODE OF ETHICS:
Members of the public body shall comply with the standards of conduct set forth
in the Utah public officers' and employees' ethics act. Members of the public
body shall properly disclose all personal and/or business interests that create
a substantial conflict between his/her private interests and his/her public
duties. In the event a member is an applicant or presenter of an item that is
before the public body for decision, the member should not participate as a
member of the public body regarding that item, either in the discussion or
voting concerning that item. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
PART 6. AMENDING OR WAIVING RULES
2.06.601: AMENDMENT OF RULES OF PROCEDURE:
These rules of procedure may be amended by a future ordinance adopted by the
city council. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.602: WAIVING OR SUSPENDING RULES:
A rule of procedure may be suspended or waived at any meeting by a majority
vote of public body members present, unless such rule is set by state law or
city ordinance. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
2.06.603: TEMPORARY RULE:
A temporary rule of procedure, in conformity with state law and city ordinance,
may be adopted by the public body for a meeting or agenda item following a
unanimous vote of the public body members present. (Ord. 2011-10, 2011)
CHAPTER 7
ARTS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.07.101: Creation, Number Of Members, Appointment
2.07.102: Powers And Duties
2.07.103: Term Of Office
2.07.104: Officers, Rules And Procedures
2.07.105: Notice Of Vacancies
2.07.106: Removals For Not Attending Meetings
2.07.107: Compensation; Cost Reimbursement
2.07.108: Meetings
2.07.109: Quorum And Vote
2.07.101: CREATION, NUMBER OF MEMBERS, APPOINTMENT:
The Ivins arts commission shall consist of seven (7) members to be appointed by
the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. It is the intent of
this chapter that the arts commission consist of a majority of members who
reside in Ivins and who, in the aggregate, have broad experience and expertise
in the arts and/or arts organization management and such other characteristics
valued by the city council. No member of the arts commission shall be an
elected official or an employee of Ivins City. (Ord. 2015-20, 2015)
2.07.102: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Ivins City arts commission shall have all powers necessary to fulfill the
following duties:
   (1)   Recommend to the city council how the arts master plan can best be
implemented;
   (2)   Recommend to the city council persons to be appointed to the arts
commission;
   (3)   Periodically review the arts master plan in accordance with its
provisions and recommend to the city council revisions to the plan when
warranted;
   (4)   Recommend to the city council applicants to receive RAP tax funding
for the arts under the competitive process set forth by the city council; and
   (5)   With the consent of the City Council, apply for art grant funds on
behalf of Ivins City. Prior to submitting an art grant fund application, the
arts commission shall provide the Director of Finance with a copy of the
application for determination if there is a contributory match requirement. To
expend funds obtained in this manner, the arts commission shall submit a check
request, with supporting documentation, to the Director of Finance for review,
processing, and payment.
   (6)   Apply for uncommitted arts RAP tax funds on behalf of Ivins City. To
expend funds obtained in this manner, the arts commission shall submit a check
request, with supporting documentation, to the Director of Finance for review,
processing, and payment.
(Ord. 2015-20, 2015; amd. Ord. 2019-05, 2019)
2.07.103: TERM OF OFFICE:
The term of office for each arts commission member shall be two (2) years. An
arts commission member may serve no more than three (3) consecutive two (2)
year terms. Terms of office shall begin on April 1 of each calendar year,
except that the city council may appoint the first members of the arts
commission to serve for staggered terms of one or two (2) years. (Ord. 2015-20,
2015)
2.07.104: OFFICERS, RULES AND PROCEDURES:
The officers of the arts commission shall be a chair and vice chair. A deputy
city recorder shall record and take minutes of the meetings of the arts
commission and the commission shall follow the rules of order and procedure set
forth in chapter 6 of this title. At its first meeting, and annually
thereafter, the members of the arts commission shall elect by a majority vote
such officers from among the members. The terms of each officer shall begin on
the day of election and continue until a successor is elected. No arts
commission member may serve more than one consecutive term in the same officer
position, but may again be elected to serve in the position once held so long
as he/she has been out of the office for at least one term. (Ord. 2015-20,
2015)
2.07.105: NOTICE OF VACANCIES:
Prior to the expiration of a sitting arts commission member's term, the mayor
may publish, through usual and customary methods, a notice of the vacancy and
the application deadline to be considered for appointment. Vacancies of
appointed members occurring for any reason other than the expiration of the
member's term may be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by
appointment. (Ord. 2015-20, 2015)
2.07.106: REMOVALS FOR NOT ATTENDING MEETINGS:
An arts commission member who misses three (3) consecutive arts commission
meetings shall be deemed to have resigned and automatically removed from the
arts commission. (Ord. 2015-20, 2015)
2.07.107: COMPENSATION; COST REIMBURSEMENT:
The members of the arts commission shall serve without compensation; however,
members of the arts commission shall be reimbursed for previously approved
expenditures by following the process outlined in the city's purchasing
ordinance. (Ord. 2015-20, 2015)
2.07.108: MEETINGS:
The arts commission shall meet at least quarterly. The dates and agendas for
all arts commission meetings shall be posted in accordance with the usual
procedures used by Ivins City for public notice. Arts commission meetings shall
be open to the public and held in Ivins City Hall or such other location deemed
appropriate. The arts commission may receive and consider public input as
needed on various issues pertaining to the scope and purpose of the arts
commission. (Ord. 2015-20, 2015)
2.07.109: QUORUM AND VOTE:
A quorum shall consist of four (4) members. No business may be conducted on any
matter unless a quorum is present. A simple majority vote of members present is
required to take action on any matter. (Ord. 2015-20, 2015)
TITLE 3
REVENUE AND FINANCE
CHAPTER 1
USE AND DISPOSAL OF CITY PROPERTY
SECTION:
Part 1. Use Of City Property
3.01.101: Unlawful Use
3.01.102: Exemptions
3.01.103: Repair Or Restoration
3.01.104: Franchise To Use Property
Part 2. Disposal Of City Owned Personal Property
3.01.201: Petition City Council
3.01.202: Advertisement For Sale
3.01.203: Property With No Resale Value
3.01.204: Removal Of Disposed Property From City Assets
Part 3. Disposal Of City Owned Real Property
3.01.301: Definitions
3.01.302: Notice; Public Comment
3.01.303: City Council Approval Required
PART 1. USE OF CITY PROPERTY
3.01.101: UNLAWFUL USE:
Unless authorized by permit or other written authorization issued by the city,
or unless authority is granted by provisions of this code or other ordinance of
the city now or hereafter enacted, it shall be a class B misdemeanor for any
person to:
   (1)   Construct, lay, excavate, erect, operate or maintain over, under,
across, in or through any property owned or controlled by this city any
utility, canal, ditch, construction or building;
   (2)   Enter upon any property of this city contrary to posting or marking
restricting or prohibiting use of the area; or
   (3)   Intentionally use or perform acts upon property of the city that
materially impairs, alters or damages the property. (Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
3.01.102: EXEMPTIONS:
It shall not be a violation of this chapter when any person uses the public
property of this city in the manner or for the purpose or purposes for which
such property has been made available for public use. (Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
3.01.103: REPAIR OR RESTORATION:
The city council, in addition to any other penalty, which may be imposed, may
order any person who has damaged, altered or changed any property of this city
to repair or restore the property to its condition prior to the damage,
alteration or change. (Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
3.01.104: FRANCHISE TO USE PROPERTY:
   (1)   The city council may grant to any person a franchise or easement on
such terms and conditions as it deems reasonable, for the purpose of entering
upon, constructing, building, operating and maintaining any business or for
other use of the property of this city, and the provisions of sections
3.01.101 and
3.01.102 of this chapter shall not apply to the extent such provisions are
waived, qualified or made inapplicable to the rights or privileges granted in
the franchise ordinance or easement.
   (2)   Any franchise or easement granted by this city shall be in writing and
any franchise or easement not in writing shall be void. (Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
PART 2. DISPOSAL OF CITY OWNED PERSONAL PROPERTY
3.01.201: PETITION CITY COUNCIL:
Department heads shall petition the city council for approval to classify as,
and then dispose of, any city owned personal property that is considered
surplus, obsolete or unusable. (Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
3.01.202: ADVERTISEMENT FOR SALE:
Any surplus personal property determined to have a resale value of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more shall be advertised for sale by the city
recorder. The city may refuse any or all bids on items offered for sale. (Ord.
2010-16, 2010)
3.01.203: PROPERTY WITH NO RESALE VALUE:
Property not deemed to have a resale value of at least five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) shall be disposed of by the department head in a manner deemed to
be in the best interest of the public and approved by the city manager. (Ord.
2010-16, 2010)
3.01.204: REMOVAL OF DISPOSED PROPERTY FROM CITY ASSETS:
The department head shall provide the director of finance with a list of all
such property disposed of so that it may be removed from the list of city
assets. (Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
PART 3. DISPOSAL OF CITY OWNED REAL PROPERTY
3.01.301: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
CITY OWNED REAL PROPERTY: Any parcel of real property owned by the city,
excluding real property held jointly with other entities.
DISPOSAL OR DISPOSITION: The alienation of city owned real property by sale,
trade, or transfer of title.
SIGNIFICANT PARCEL: Any city owned real property. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.01.302: NOTICE; PUBLIC COMMENT:
Before the city disposes of a significant parcel of real property, the city
shall provide public notice of the proposed disposition and of a public hearing
to receive public comment on the proposed disposition. Notice of the public
hearing for a proposal to vacate a public street, right of way, or easement
shall be governed by section 10-9a-208 of the Utah code, as amended. All other
types of notices to dispose of real property shall be given at least fourteen
(14) days before the public hearing, shall give the date, time and place of the
public hearing, and shall be:
   (1)   Published in a newspaper of general circulation in the area;
   (2)   Published on the Utah public notice website; and
   (3)   Posted at city hall and on the city's website. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.01.303: CITY COUNCIL APPROVAL REQUIRED:
Approval of the city council shall be required for the disposition of any
significant parcels of city owned real property, such approval coming after a
public hearing thereon has been held and finding made that it would be in the
city's best interest to proceed with the proposed disposition. The city council
shall also approve contracts related to the proposed disposition of significant
parcels of city owned real property. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
CHAPTER 2
MUNICIPAL TRANSIENT ROOM TAX
SECTION:
3.02.101: Purpose
3.02.102: Collection Of Tax
3.02.103: Revenue Use
3.02.101: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to impose the maximum tax allowed by section
59-12-352 of the Utah code (currently 1 percent) on charges for the
accommodations and services described in subsection 59-12-103(1)(i), as
amended. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.02.102: COLLECTION OF TAX:
   (1)   The tax imposed above shall be collected and distributed as set forth
in section 59-12-354 of the Utah code, as amended. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.02.103: REVENUE USE:
All revenues generated by the transient room tax shall be added to the general
fund and the uses of the funds will be budgeted under the auspices of the
general fund. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
CHAPTER 3
LOCAL SALES AND USE TAX
SECTION:
3.03.101: Purpose
3.03.102: Sales And Use Tax Levied
3.03.103: State Statutes Incorporated
3.03.104: Report Of Tax Collection; Point Of Sale; Public Utilities
3.03.105: Contract With State Tax Commission
3.03.106: Exemption From Tax
3.03.107: Tax Paid Not Part Of Purchase Price
3.03.101: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to conform the sales and use tax of the city
to the requirements of the sales and use tax act, Utah Code Annotated title 59,
chapter 12, parts 1 and 2, 1953, as amended. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.03.102: SALES AND USE TAX LEVIED:
There is hereby levied, and there shall be collected and paid, a tax upon every
transaction listed in Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-103(1) of the sales and
use tax act made within the city at the rate of one percent (1%). (Ord. 2016-
23, 2016)
3.03.103: STATE STATUTES INCORPORATED:
   (1)   Except as herein provided, and except insofar as they are inconsistent
with the provisions of the sales and use tax act, all of the provisions of Utah
Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, parts 1 and 2, 1953, as amended, in force
and effect on the effective date hereof, insofar as they relate to sales and
use taxes, excepting sections 59-12-101 and 59-12-119 thereof, are adopted and
made a part of this chapter as though fully set forth herein.
   (2)   Wherever, and to the extent that in Utah Code Annotated title 59,
chapter 12, part 1, 1953, the state of Utah is named or referred to as the
taxing agency, the name of this city shall be substituted therefor. Nothing in
this subsection shall be deemed to require substitution of the name of the city
for the word "state" when that word is used as part of the title of the state
tax commission, or of the constitution of the state of Utah, nor shall the name
of the city be substituted for that of the state in any section when the result
of that substitution would require action to be taken by or against the city or
any agency thereof, rather than by or against the state tax commission in
performing the functions incident to the administration or operation of this
chapter.
   (3)   Any amendments made by the Utah legislature to Utah Code Annotated
title 59, chapter 12, parts 1 and/or 2, 1953, as amended, which would be
applicable to the city, are hereby incorporated herein by reference and shall
be effective upon the date they are effective as a Utah statute. (Ord. 2016-23,
2016)
3.03.104: REPORT OF TAX COLLECTION; POINT OF SALE; PUBLIC UTILITIES:
All sales and use taxes collected under this chapter shall be reported to the
state tax commission on forms, which accurately identify the location where the
sale or use transaction was consummated. If a retailer has no permanent place
of business in the state or has more than one place of business, the place or
places at which the retail sales are consummated for the purposes of this
chapter shall be determined under rules of the state tax commission. "Public
utilities", as defined by Utah Code Annotated title 54, 1953, as amended, shall
not be obligated to determine the place or places within the city where public
utility services are rendered, and the state tax commission shall apportion the
revenues arising from such services on an equitable basis pursuant to an
appropriate formula and under rules to be prescribed and adopted by it. (Ord.
2016-23, 2016)
3.03.105: CONTRACT WITH STATE TAX COMMISSION:
Pursuant to agreement, the state tax commission has been performing all
functions incident to the administration or operation of the sales and use tax
ordinance of the city. That agreement is hereby confirmed and the mayor is
authorized to enter into such supplementary agreement with the state tax
commission as may be necessary for the continued administration and operation
of the sales and use tax ordinance of the city as enacted by this chapter.
(Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.03.106: EXEMPTION FROM TAX:
The sale, storage, use or other consumption of tangible personal property, the
gross receipts from the sale of or the cost of which has been subject to sales
or use tax under a sales and use tax ordinance enacted in accordance with Utah
Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 2, 1953, as amended, by a county
other than Washington County or by any other Utah city or town shall be exempt
from the tax. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.03.107: TAX PAID NOT PART OF PURCHASE PRICE:
The amount of any tax paid under Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part
1, 1953, as amended, shall not be included as a part of the purchase price paid
or charged for a taxable item hereunder. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
CHAPTER 4
SPECIAL IMPROVEMENT GUARANTY FUND
(Rep. by Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
CHAPTER 5
SPECIAL IMPROVEMENT TAXES
(Rep. by Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
CHAPTER 6
MUNICIPAL ENERGY SALES AND USE TAX
SECTION:
3.06.101: Purpose
3.06.102: Definitions
3.06.103: Energy Sales And Use Tax
3.06.104: Exemptions From Energy Sales And Use Tax
3.06.105: Existing Franchise Agreements
3.06.106: Collection Of Taxes By State Tax Commission
3.06.107: State Statutes Incorporated
3.06.108: Additional License For Collection Of Tax Not Required
3.06.101: PURPOSE:
It is the intent of the city council to provide both a stable revenue source
and create a more competitive environment for the energy industry by repealing
its utility franchise tax levied on gas and electricity and adopting a
municipal energy sales and use tax pursuant to, and in conformance with, Utah
Code Annotated section 10-1-301 et seq., the municipal energy sales and use tax
act. (Ord. 2000-12, 2000)
3.06.102: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
COMMISSION: The state tax commission.
CONSUMER: A person who acquires taxable energy for any use that is subject to
the energy sales and use tax.
CONTRACTUAL FRANCHISE FEE: (1) A fee provided for in a franchise agreement and
that is consideration for the franchise agreement; or
   (2)   A fee similar to subsection (1) of this definition; or
   (3)   Any combination of subsections (1) and (2) of this definition.
DE MINIMIS AMOUNT: An amount of taxable energy that does not exceed the greater
of:
   (1)   Five percent (5%) of the energy supplier's estimated total Utah gross
receipts from sales of property or services; or
   (2)   Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
DELIVERED VALUE: (1) The fair market value of taxable energy delivered for sale
or use in the municipality and includes:
      (a)   The value of the energy itself; and
      (b)   Any transportation, freight, customer demand charges, service
charges, or other costs typically incurred in providing taxable energy in
usable form to each class of customer in the municipality.
   (2)   "Delivered value" does not include the tax paid under:
      (a)   Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 1, tax collection;
      (b)   Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 2, the local sales
and use tax act.
ENERGY SUPPLIER: A person supplying taxable energy, except that the commission
may by rule exclude from this definition a person supplying a de minimis amount
of taxable energy.
FRANCHISE AGREEMENT: A franchise or an ordinance, contract or agreement
granting a franchise.
FRANCHISE TAX: (1) A franchise tax;
   (2)   A tax similar to a franchise tax; or
   (3)   Any combination of subsections (1) and (2) of this definition.
PERSON: As defined in Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-102(10).
SALE: Any transfer of title, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in
any manner, of taxable energy for a consideration. It includes:
   (1)   Installment sales;
   (2)   Any closed transaction constituting a sale;
   (3)   Any transaction under which right to acquire, use or consume taxable
energy is granted incident to the ownership or the leasing of the taxable
energy.
STORAGE: Any keeping or retention of taxable energy in Ivins City for any
purpose except sale in the regular course of business.
TAXABLE ENERGY: Gas and electricity.
USE: The exercise of any right or power over taxable energy incident to the
ownership or the leasing of the taxable energy. "Use" does not include the
sale, display, demonstration or trial of the taxable energy in the regular
course of business and held for resale. (Ord. 2000-12, 2000)
3.06.103: ENERGY SALES AND USE TAX:
There is hereby levied, subject to the provisions of this chapter, a tax on
every sale or use of taxable energy made within the city equaling six percent
(6%) of the delivered value of the taxable energy to the consumer. This tax
shall be known as the "energy sales and use tax".
   (1)   The tax shall be calculated on the delivered value of the taxable
energy to the consumer.
   (2)   The tax shall be in addition to any sales or use tax on taxable energy
imposed by the city or the state. (Ord. 2005-11, 2005)
3.06.104: EXEMPTIONS FROM ENERGY SALES AND USE TAX:
   (1)   Pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-305(2)(b), the following
are exempt from the energy sales and use tax:
      (a)   Sales and use of aviation fuel, motor fuel, or special fuel subject
to taxation under Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 13;
      (b)   The sales and use of taxable energy that the city is prohibited
from taxing under federal law or the constitution of the United States or the
Utah constitution;
      (c)   The sales and use of taxable energy purchased or stored in the
state for resale;
      (d)   The sales or use of taxable energy to a person if the primary use
is for compounding or producing taxable energy or fuel subject to taxation
under Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 13, motor and special fuel tax act;
      (e)   Taxable energy brought into the state by a nonresident for the
nonresident's own personal use or enjoyment while within the state, except
taxable energy purchased for use in the state by a nonresident living or
working in the state at the time of purchase;
      (f)   The sales or use of taxable energy for any purpose other than use
as a fuel; and
      (g)   The sale of taxable energy for use outside the corporate limits of
the city.
   (2)   The sale, storage, use or other consumption of taxable energy is
exempt from the energy sales and use tax levied by this chapter, provided:
      (a)   The delivered value of the taxable energy has been subject to a
municipal energy sales or use tax levied by another municipality within the
state; and
      (b)   The city has paid the difference between the tax paid to the other
municipality and the tax that would otherwise be due under this chapter, if the
tax due under this chapter exceeds the tax paid to the other municipality.
   (3)   No exemptions shall be granted from the energy sales and use tax
imposed by this chapter except those specifically set forth in this section.
(Ord. 2000-12, 2000)
3.06.105: EXISTING FRANCHISE AGREEMENTS:
This chapter, as amended, shall not alter any existing franchise agreements
between the city and energy suppliers, except that any franchise fees
previously imposed on the sale or use of taxable energy within the city are
hereby repealed and replaced with the energy sales and use tax set forth in
this chapter. (Ord. 2005-11, 2005)
3.06.106: COLLECTION OF TAXES BY STATE TAX COMMISSION:
   (1)   On or before the effective date hereof, the city shall contract with
the state tax commission to perform all functions incident to the
administration and collection of the energy sales and use tax, in accordance
with this chapter. This contract may be a supplement to the existing contract
with the commission to administer and collect the local sales and use tax, as
provided in this code. The city may enter into supplementary agreements with
the state tax commission as may be necessary and proper for the continued
administration and operation of the energy sales and use tax ordinance enacted
by this chapter.
   (2)   An energy supplier shall pay the energy sales and use tax revenue
collected from consumers directly to the city if:
      (a)   The city is the energy supplier; or
      (b)   The energy supplier estimates that the municipal energy sales and
use tax collected annually from its Utah customers equals one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) or more; and
      (c)   The energy supplier collects the energy sales and use tax. (Ord.
2000-12, 2000)
3.06.107: STATE STATUTES INCORPORATED:
   (1)   Except as herein provided, and except insofar as they are inconsistent
with the provisions of Utah Code Annotated title 10, chapter 1, part 3,
municipal energy sales and use tax act, as well as this chapter, all of the
provisions of Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 1, as amended, and
in force and effect on the effective date hereof, insofar as they relate to
sales and use taxes, excepting sections 59-12-101 and 59-12-119 thereof, and
excepting for the amount of the sales and use taxes levied therein, are adopted
and made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein.
   (2)   Wherever and to the extent that in Utah Code Annotated title 59,
chapter 12, part 1, as amended, the state of Utah is named or referred to as
the taxing agency, the name of Ivins City shall be substituted, insofar as is
necessary for the purposes of that part, as well as Utah Code Annotated title
10, chapter 1, part 3, as amended. Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed
to require substitution of the name Ivins City for the word "state" when that
word is used as part of the title of the state tax commission, or of the
constitution of the state, nor shall the name of Ivins City be substituted for
that of the "state" in any section when the result of such substitution would
require action to be taken by or against the city or any agency thereof, rather
than by or against the state tax commission in performing the functions
incident to the administration or operation of this chapter.
   (3)   Any amendments made to Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part
1, as amended, which would be applicable to the city for the purposes of
carrying out this chapter are incorporated herein by reference and shall be
effective upon the date that they are effective as a Utah statute. (Ord. 2000-
12, 2000)
3.06.108: ADDITIONAL LICENSE FOR COLLECTION OF TAX NOT REQUIRED:
No additional license to collect or report the municipal energy sales and use
tax is required, provided the energy supplier collecting the tax has a license
issued under Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-106. (Ord. 2000-12, 2000)

3.07.101: Municipal Telecommunications License Tax

3.07.103: Collection Of Taxes By State Tax Commission

(currently 3.5 percent). (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)

tax commission to perform all functions incident to the administration and
collection of the municipal telecommunications license tax, in accordance with
this chapter. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)

CHAPTER 10
DONATIONS
SECTION:
3.10.101: Purpose
3.10.102: Definitions
3.10.103: Funds; Accounting
3.10.104: Acceptance Of Monetary Donations
3.10.105: Acceptance Of Nonmonetary Donations
3.10.101: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to authorize the acceptance of donations for any
public use by the city and to specify policies and procedures for doing so.
(Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.10.102: DEFINITIONS:
DONATION: Any monetary or nonmonetary contribution, gift, grant, devise or
bequest to the city.
   (1)   A monetary donation includes cash or a check, money order or other
negotiable instrument.
   (2)   A nonmonetary donation includes real or personal property. In the
event of a stock donation, such a donation would be liquidated and turned into
cash or another liquid asset and treated as a monetary donation.
   (3)   All donations not meeting the definition of a "restricted donation"
shall be unrestricted and the city shall have absolute discretion to use the
donations for any purpose.
RESTRICTED DONATION: A donation that can only be used by the city for a special
purpose specified in writing by the donor and agreed to by the city.
   (1)   Prior to accepting a restricted donation, the person authorized to
approve the acceptance of such donation shall consider the impacts of the
donation, including impacts on future or ongoing operations or capital costs
associated with the donation.
   (2)   Restricted donations shall be deposited into the appropriate fund/
account for the purpose specified by the donor and agreed to by the city. (Ord.
2016-23, 2016)
3.10.103: FUNDS; ACCOUNTING:
The city treasurer shall be responsible for depositing all donations in a
timely manner. The director of finance shall track the proposed use of any such
donations and shall maintain separate records of accounts showing receipts and
disbursements. The director of finance may establish further rules and
regulations for the accounting and administration of donations, consistent with
this chapter. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.10.104: ACCEPTANCE OF MONETARY DONATIONS:
   (1)   Donations Under Five Thousand Dollars: Department heads are authorized
to approve the acceptance of any monetary donations of less than five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) on behalf of the city. All such donations shall only be
received by city employees authorized and bonded to receive money on behalf of
the city and all donations shall be turned over to the city treasurer to be
deposited into the appropriate account.
   (2)   Donations Under Ten Thousand Dollars: The city manager is authorized
to approve the acceptance of any monetary donations of less than ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) on behalf of the city. All such donations shall only be
received by city employees authorized and bonded to receive money on behalf of
the city and all donations shall be turned over to the city treasurer to be
deposited into the appropriate account.
   (3)   Donations Greater Than Ten Thousand Dollars: The city council shall
approve the acceptance of any monetary donations greater than ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) on behalf of the city. All such donations shall only be
received by city employees authorized and bonded to receive money on behalf of
the city and all donations shall be turned over to the city treasurer to be
deposited into the appropriate account. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
3.10.105: ACCEPTANCE OF NONMONETARY DONATIONS:
All nonmonetary donations shall be reported to the director of finance for
booking and tracking of city assets.
   (1)   Donations Under Five Thousand Dollars: Department heads are authorized
to approve the acceptance of any nonmonetary donations of personal property
valued at less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) on behalf of the city.
   (2)   Donations Under Ten Thousand Dollars: The city manager is authorized
to approve the acceptance of any nonmonetary donations of personal property
valued at less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) on behalf of the city.
   (3)   Donations Greater Than Ten Thousand Dollars: The city council shall
approve the acceptance of any nonmonetary donations of personal property valued
at greater than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or any donation involving
real property, on behalf of the city. All such donations shall be handled by
and through the city attorney. (Ord. 2016-23, 2016)
