Notes
1 1. See chapter 1 of this title.
PART 1. GENERAL PROVISIONS
3.12.101: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish a policy and procedure for
purchases and payments made by the city. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.102: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
BIDDING: The procedure used to solicit quotations on price and delivery from
various prospective suppliers of supplies, equipment and/or contractual
services.
BUILDING IMPROVEMENT: Includes any repair, maintenance or construction of city
owned buildings.
BUSINESS: Any corporation, limited corporation, partnership, individual, sole
proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture, or any other private legal
entity.
CHANGE ORDER: A written order directing the contractor to suspend work or make
changes, which the appropriate clauses of the contract authorize, without the
consent of the contractor, or any written alteration in specifications,
delivery point, rate of delivery, period of performance, price, quantity or
other provisions of any contract accomplished by mutual action of the parties
to the contract.
CITY: When used in this chapter, refers to Ivins City.
CONTRACT: Any city agreement for the procurement or disposal of supplies,
services or construction.
DEPARTMENT HEAD: That individual who administers a department or his/her
designee as specified in writing to the purchasing agent or, in the absence of
a department head, the city manager.
EMERGENCY CONDITION: A situation that creates a threat to public health,
welfare or safety.
FIXED ASSET: Capital asset purchased for or valued at five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) or greater.
INVITATION FOR BIDS: All documents, whether attached or incorporated by
reference, used for soliciting bids.
OFFEROR: Person submitting the bid. See also definition of Responsible Bidder.
PAYMENT BOND: A contract of guaranty for the protection of each person
supplying labor, service, equipment or material for the performance of the work
provided for in a contract.
PERFORMANCE BOND: A contract of guaranty executed subsequent to award by a
successful bidder to protect the city from loss due to the inability of the
bidder to complete the contract as agreed.
PERSON: Any business, individual, union, committee, club, other organizations
or group of individuals.
PROCUREMENT: Purchasing, renting, leasing, leasing with an option to purchase,
or otherwise acquiring any supplies, services or construction.
PROFESSIONAL SERVICES: Services such as auditing, architects, engineers,
consulting, contracts or other service providers.
PUBLIC WORKS PROJECT: Includes any repair, maintenance or construction of
streets, water transportation and storage, sewer, and storm drain projects.
PURCHASE DESCRIPTION: The words used in a solicitation to describe the
supplies, services or construction to be purchased and includes specifications
attached to or made a part of the solicitation.
PURCHASE ORDER: Official document used in committing city funds for the
purchase of supplies, equipment or services.
PURCHASING AGENT: That person duly authorized by the city manager to administer
purchasing policies and regulations.
REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS (RFP): All documents, whether attached or incorporated by
reference, utilized for proposal solicitation.
RESPONSIBLE BIDDER: A bidder who submits a responsible bid; who has furnished,
when requested, information and data to prove that his financial resources,
production or service facilities, service reputation and experience are
adequate to make satisfactory delivery of the supplies, equipment or
contractual services on which he bids; and who has not violated or attempted to
violate any provisions of this chapter.
ROUTINE EXPENSES: Expenses such as payroll, payroll taxes and related expenses,
utility bills and similar expenses, payment for previously approved leases,
contracts, professional services and maintenance of city equipment and
property. Included in the definition of a "routine expense" is any expense for:
   (1)   A tangible or intangible good that may aid in the performance of the
work of the city, including but not limited to supplies, equipment, vehicles,
software, etc.; provided however that such item must at a minimum be (a)
generally identified by type (i.e., "truck," "software," etc.) in the approved
annual budget and therein assigned a specific amount constituting the maximum
amount that can be spent on the item without obtaining additional approval by
the city council and (b) actually cost less than the specified maximum amount;
and
   (2)   A service that occurs at least annually, including but not limited to
maintenance of city equipment and property such as road resurfacing, etc., that
was anticipated when the annual budget was approved and which, if paid, will
not exceed the total appropriated amount for that category of expense as
reflected in the approved annual budget.
   A "routine expense" does not include any expense related to a new building
improvement, a new capital improvement project, or a new professional service
contract until such building improvement, capital improvement project, or
professional service contract has otherwise been approved as required by this
chapter or other applicable law.
SPECIFICATION: Any description of the physical or functional characteristics,
or of the nature of a supply, service or construction item. It may include a
description of any requirement for inspection, testing, or preparing a supply,
service or construction item for delivery.
(Ord. 2006-27, 2006; amd. Ord. 2024-14, 8-15-2024)
3.12.103: ETHICS OF PUBLIC CONTRACTING:
   (1)   No person involved in making procurement decisions may have personal
investments in any business entity the city contracts with, as this will create
a substantial conflict between their private interests and their public duties.
   (2)   Any person involved in making procurement decisions is guilty of a
felony if the person asks for, receives, or offers to receive any emolument,
gratuity, contribution, loan or reward, or any promise thereof, either for the
person's own use or the use or benefit of any other person or organization,
from any person or organization interested in selling to the city. (Ord. 2006-
27, 2006)
3.12.104: GREATER RESTRICTIONS PREVAIL:
In the interpretation and application of this chapter, the provisions of this
chapter shall be considered as minimum requirements. Where the provisions of
any statute, other regulation, ordinance or covenant imposes greater
restrictions than the provisions of this chapter, the provisions of such
statute, other regulation, ordinance or covenant shall prevail. (Ord. 2006-27,
2006)
3.12.105: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is for
any reason to be held invalid, that section shall be severed from the chapter
and shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this chapter.
(Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.106: CONTRACTOR VERIFICATION OF EMPLOYMENT ELIGIBILITY:
   (1)   Purpose: The purpose of this section is to promote compliance with
federal and state laws governing employment eligibility and verification of
workers by entities that contract with the city.
   (2)   Contractor Verification:
      (a)   All requests for proposals and all contracts for the procurement of
goods and services under this chapter shall contain the following statement:
By submitting a proposal and/or by signing this contract, contractor certifies
that it does not and will not, during the performance of this contract,
knowingly employ or subcontract with any entity which employs workers in
violation of 8 U.S.C. §1324a. Contractor agrees to produce, at the City's
request, such documents which are required to verify compliance with applicable
federal and state laws. If the contractor knowingly employs workers in
violation of 8 U.S.C. §1324a, such violation shall be cause for unilateral
cancellation of the contract between contractor and the City. In the event this
contract is terminated due to violation of 8 U.S.C. §1324a by the contractor or
by a subcontractor of the contractor, the contractor shall be liable for any
and all costs associated with such termination including, but not limited to,
any damages incurred by the City, as well as attorney's fees.
      (b)   The foregoing statement shall also be accompanied by a signature
line for the contractor to sign, thereby acknowledging that the contractor has
read, understands, and agrees to comply with the requirements of federal and
state law regarding eligibility of workers.
   (3)   Use Of Status Verification System: As required by section 63G-11-103
of the Utah code:
      (a)   Required: A contractor shall register and participate in the status
verification system in order to enter into a contract with the city; and
      (b)   Verification Of Eligibility: The city will not enter into a
contract for the physical performance of services within the state with a
contractor unless the contractor registers and participates in the status
verification system to verify the work eligibility status of the contractor's
new employees that are employed in the state.
      (c)   Exception: This subsection (3) does not apply to contracts entered
into prior to July 1, 2009, or that involve underwriting, remarketing, broker-
dealer activities, securities placement, investment advisory, financial
advisory, or other financial or investment banking services. (Ord. 2008-12,
2008)
PART 2. PURCHASING AUTHORITY
3.12.201: PURCHASE ORDERS REQUIRED:
   (1)   A purchase order shall be used whenever goods and limited services are
to be acquired by outright purchase in an amount exceeding one thousand dollars
($1,000.00), except when a purchasing card is used for purchases up to five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with department head approval of a cost allocation
report in lieu of a purchase order. The purchase order shall specify the nature
of the goods or services to be acquired, the purchase price or estimate
thereof, the date of the purchase, freight charges, prompt payment discounts,
the delivery date, the vendor from whom acquired, the department for whom the
acquisition is being made, the general ledger number assigning funding for the
proposed purchase, signature of purchaser, and other information that is
pertinent to the clear understanding of the purchase. The purchase order shall
incorporate by reference all the terms, conditions and specifications, if any,
contained in the related request for bids. (Ord. 2009-06, 2009; amd. Ord. 2015-
16, 2015)
   (2)   It is the policy of the city that payment for goods or services shall
not be made until the goods or services have been delivered. (Ord. 2009-06,
2009)
3.12.202: DUTIES ASSIGNED:
   (1)   Disperse Purchase Orders: The purchasing agent shall be responsible
for dispersing purchase orders, keeping records of all purchase orders, and
overseeing the operations of the purchasing function in such a manner as to
effectively execute procurement and property acquisition and disposition
policies established by the city council by policy declaration, or by the city
manager by way of administrative directive, and as incorporated in this
chapter.
   (2)   Duties Delegated: The city manager may delegate purchasing
responsibility to an employee on a temporary basis. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.203: AUTHORIZATION REQUIRED:
   (1)   Purchase orders shall require authorization as follows:
 
Amount                              Authorization Required
Up to $10,000                       Department Head
Over $10,000 up to $25,000          Department Head and City Manager
Over $25,000 - routine expenses     Department Head and City Manager
Over $25,000 - non-routine expenses Department Head, City Manager, and City
                                    Council
 
   (2)   Authorization of purchase orders for expenditures within the amounts
specified above shall be made prior to the purchase of any item or service.
Each department head approving a routine expense greater than twenty-five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall provide the city council with a report of
such expense within 30 days of approving the expense. The city manager shall
ensure that such reports are timely made to the city council.
   (3)   All purchase orders for expenditures over twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00), excluding routine expenses, shall be approved by the city council
prior to the purchase of any item or service.
   (4)   The department head's approval on all purchase orders shall signify
that there are sufficient unencumbered funds in the requesting department's
appropriated budget for the purchase.
   (5)   Nothing in this section removes any other procurement process or
requirement as described in this chapter or any other applicable law, including
but not limited to any requirement to obtain bids/quotes or follow specified
standards for selection or awards, etc.
(Ord. 2015-16, 2015; amd. Ord. 2023-07, 2023; Ord. 2024-14, 8-15-2024)
3.12.204: DEPARTMENT HEAD AUTHORIZATION:
   Each department head shall be authorized to purchase items costing up to ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and to disperse and authorize use of the purchase
orders which the department head has received from the purchasing agent.
(Ord. 2006-27, 2006; amd. Ord. 2015-16, 2015; amd. Ord. 2023-07, 2023; Ord.
2024-14, 8-15-2024)
3.12.205: ROUTING:
A purchase order number shall be issued to the vendor at the time the purchase
is made. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.206: CHECK SIGNING:
Checks for all expenditures shall be signed by the city treasurer, or in his/
her absence the deputy treasurer, and the city recorder, or in his/her absence
an authorized designee, after written approval of the check register by the
city manager. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.207: PURCHASING AGENT RESPONSIBILITIES:
The purchasing agent shall periodically review lists of approved vendors, being
alert to unknown vendors, vendors with names similar to other known vendors,
vendors with no physical address or telephone number, vendors whose addresses
match employee addresses, and certify that purchase orders are preapproved by
the appropriate signatures. The purchasing agent shall determine that there are
sufficient unencumbered funds in the appropriated budget for purchases
requested on a purchase order. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.208: CITY MANAGER RESPONSIBILITIES:
   (1)   The city manager shall review the contents of all bank statements and
review all bank reconciliations. The city manager's review shall include
accounting for all checks and the sequence of checks, making sure all payees
are known and recognizable, checking for alteration of any checks, being sure
all checks are signed by authorized signatories, and being alert to any other
unusual items. The city manager shall approve all transfers of money between
city accounts.
   (2)   In addition, the city manager shall be alert to any changes in
employee attitudes, behavior and lifestyles and shall also require all
employees responsible for cash receipting, cash management, or accounting to
take a minimum of five (5) consecutive days of vacation during each calendar
year. In addition, the city manager shall provide an opportunity for employees
to anonymously report the occurrence of fraud or other misconduct. (Ord. 2009-
06, 2009)
PART 3. BIDDING REQUIREMENTS
3.12.301: COMPETITIVE BID REQUIRED FOR BUILDING IMPROVEMENTS:
   (1)   Bid Requirements: All purchases and contracts, whether by sealed bid,
quotation or negotiation, shall be made on a competitive basis to the maximum
practical extent, except as noted below:
 
Amount Of Purchase      Bid Required
Up to $1,000.00         No bid required; competitive quotes recommended
$1,001.00 to $40,000.00 Informal bids required (2 if possible)
Over $40,000.00         Formal bid required
 
   (2)   Amounts In Excess Of Forty Thousand Dollars:
      (a)   If the improvement is a building improvement and the estimated cost
of the improvement is in excess of forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00), the
city shall, if it determines to do the work, only do so by contract let to the
lowest responsible bidder after publication of notice at least twice in a
newspaper of general circulation printed and published in the city at least
five (5) days prior to the opening of bids.
      (b)   The term "lowest responsible bidder" means any prime contractor who
has bid in compliance with the invitation to bid and within the requirements of
the plans and specifications for a construction project, who is the lowest
bidder, who has furnished a bid bond or equivalent in money as a condition to
the award of a prime contract and who furnishes a payment and performance bond
as required by law.
      (c)   When the cost of a contemplated improvement exceeds the bid
requirement sum, the job cannot be divided into smaller jobs to avoid having to
bid the job.
      (d)   The purchasing agent shall send out all bids based on the
information provided by the department head and shall keep a list of the date
the bids were mailed and a list of the vendors to whom the bids were mailed.
The purchasing agent shall also receive all bids and keep a list of the date
and time they were received. Whenever practical, the opening of the bids shall
be made in the presence of the department head and the city recorder.
   (3)   Amounts Up To Forty Thousand Dollars But In Excess Of One Thousand
Dollars: If the improvement is a building improvement and the estimated cost of
the improvement is forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) or less, but in excess
of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the city may make the improvement without
calling for bid, except as otherwise provided within this chapter.
   (4)   Purchases Up To One Thousand Dollars; Competitive Bid Not Required:
These purchases shall be obtained by using purchase orders issued by the
department head to obtain supplies and services, which have been approved as
part of the budget.
      (a)   Written competitive bids are not required, but the department head
or his/her designee is encouraged to obtain competitive quotations.
      (b)   The employee receiving the supplies shall sign the delivery ticket
to designate that he/she obtained the supplies or services in good condition.
(Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.302: COMPETITIVE BID REQUIRED FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS:
   (1)   Requirements: All public works projects, whether by sealed bid,
quotation or negotiation, shall be made on a competitive basis to the maximum
practical extent except as noted below:
 
Amount Of Purchase       Bid Requirement
Up to $1,000.00          No bid required - competitive quotes required
$1,001.00 to $125,000.00 Informal bids required (2 if possible)
Over $125,000.00         Formal bid required
 
   (2)   Amounts In Excess Of One Hundred Twenty Five Thousand Dollars:
      (a)   If the improvement is a public works project and the estimated cost
of the improvement or maintenance of existing facilities is in excess of one
hundred twenty five thousand dollars ($125,000.00), the city shall, if it
determines to do the work, only do so by contract let to the lowest responsible
bidder after publication of notice at least twice in a newspaper of general
circulation printed and published in the city at least five (5) days prior to
the opening of bids. The cost shall be estimated by the city engineer.
      (b)   The term "lowest responsible bidder" means any prime contractor who
has bid in compliance with the invitation to bid and within the requirements of
the plans and specifications for a construction project, who is the low bidder,
who has furnished a bid bond or equivalent in money as a condition to the award
of a prime contract and who furnishes a payment and performance bond as
required by law.
      (c)   When the cost of a contemplated improvement exceeds the bid
requirement sum, the job cannot be divided into smaller jobs to avoid having to
bid the job.
      (d)   The purchasing agent shall send out all bids based on the
information provided by the department head and shall keep a list of the date
the bids were mailed and a list of the vendors to whom the bids were mailed.
The purchasing agent shall also receive all bids and keep a list of the date
and time they were received. Whenever practical, the opening of the bids shall
be made in the presence of the department head and the city recorder.
   (3)   Amounts Up To One Hundred Twenty Five Thousand Dollars, But In Excess
Of One Thousand Dollars: If the improvement is a public works project and the
estimated cost of the project is one hundred twenty five thousand dollars
($125,000.00) or less, but in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the
city may make the improvement without calling for bid, except as otherwise
provided within this chapter.
   (4)   Purchases Up To One Thousand Dollars; Competitive Bid Not Required:
These purchases shall be obtained by using purchase orders issued by the
department head to obtain supplies and services, which have been approved as
part of the budget.
      (a)   Written competitive bids are not required, but the department head
or his/her designee is encouraged to obtain competitive quotations.
      (b)   The employee receiving the supplies shall sign the delivery ticket
to designate that he/she obtained the supplies or services in good condition.
(Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.303: PROCUREMENT OF PROFESSIONAL SERVICES:
The procurement of professional services shall be based upon qualifications and
shall be secured on a competitive basis to the maximum practical extent except
as noted below:
 
Amount Of Contract                          Request For Proposals
Up to $50,000.00 per fiscal year (Utah
procurement code defines anything less than No RFP required; competitive quotes
$100,000.00 as a small contract not         recommended
requiring formal RFP procedures)
Over $50,000.00 in 1 fiscal year            Formal request for proposals
 
The city council shall approve the award of contracts for professional services
exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in any single fiscal year. The
award of contracts for professional services less than ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) may be approved jointly by the applicable department head and the
city manager. Awards shall be made to the individual or firm whose proposal is
determined to be the most advantageous to the city, taking into consideration
price and the evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals. (Ord.
2013-15, 2013)
3.12.304: PURCHASE ORDERS AND CONTRACTS NOT REQUIRING BIDS:
   (1)   Sole Source: The restrictions contained above shall not apply in cases
where purchases or contracts are for items which can only be purchased from a
single or sole source manufacturer or distributor and no reasonable similar
alternative exists. The purchase order shall justify the sole source exemption
and shall be signed by the appropriate department head and the city manager.
   (2)   Contracts Not Suited To Competitive Bidding: Contracts which by their
nature are not suited to award by competitive bidding shall not be subject to
the competitive bidding requirements of this chapter. These contracts include:
      (a)   Contracts for items that can only be purchased from a single or
sole source provider.
      (b)   Contracts for additions to and repairs and maintenance of equipment
owned by the city which may be efficiently added to, repaired or maintained by
only a particular person or firm.
      (c)   Contracts for equipment which, by reason of the training of city
personnel or the inventory of replacement parts maintained by the city, is more
compatible with the existing equipment owned by the city.
   (3)   Utilities Purchase: Utility services such as water, electric power,
natural gas and telephone, except when alternative supplies or services are
available.
   (4)   Court Fees: Witness and jury fees and other payments as may be ordered
by the court.
   (5)   Return Of Deposits: Water deposits and other deposits collected for
specific purposes may be returned upon the requirements of the deposit being
met.
   (6)   Emergency: When a public emergency will not tolerate the delay
incident to the advertising for a solicitation of bids, the department head
shall determine the emergency and then file a report with the city manager. The
city manager shall determine and approve the payment of emergency purchases
under the following conditions:
      (a)   Purchases under this subsection shall be based on a need that is
compelling and of unusual urgency, such as when the city would be seriously
injured financially or otherwise if the personal property or services were not
furnished by a certain time, and when they could not be procured by that time
by means of advertising, bidding and/or solicitations of quotations as
previously defined.
      (b)   The department for whom the emergency purchases are made shall, as
soon as practical, file a written report with the city manager, which shall
contain the following information:
         (i)   The conditions which created the emergency, and a description of
the threat to the health, welfare or safety of the public pursuant to finding
that an emergency existed;
         (ii)   The basis for the selection of the particular contractor or
supplier and a description of what efforts were utilized to identify and
contact alternative suppliers or contractors;
         (iii)   The contractor's or supplier's name and address, along with a
list of the supplies, materials, services or construction procured under the
contract;
         (iv)   Completed and signed purchase orders with attached invoices
requesting payment for the emergency purchases.
      (c)   The city manager shall review the report submitted and, if
appropriate, shall declare the condition an emergency and shall approve the
report and purchase orders and authorize the payment for the emergency
purchases.
         (i)   The city manager is empowered to declare a state of emergency,
for the purposes of this chapter, when, in his/her opinion, such a condition
exists, and, when the amount to be expended to meet such emergency does not
exceed twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00).
         (ii)   When the city manager finds and declares an emergency, the city
manager, in conjunction with the department for whom the emergency purchases
are made, shall, as soon as practical, present a written report to the mayor
and city council which shall contain the following information:
            (A)   The conditions which created the emergency, and a description
of the threat to the health, welfare or safety of the public pursuant to
finding that an emergency existed;
            (B)   The basis for the selection of the particular contractor or
supplier and a description of what efforts were made to identify and contract
alternative suppliers or contractors;
            (C)   The contractor's or supplier's name and address, along with a
list of the supplies, materials, services or construction procured under the
contract;
            (D)   Completed signed purchase orders with attached invoices
requesting payment for the emergency purchases.
         (iii)   The city council shall review the report submitted, and if
appropriate, shall ratify the city manager's declaration of the emergency
condition, and shall approve the report and requisitions and authorize the
payment of the emergency purchases.
   (7)   State Procurement Contracts:
      (a)   Purchases made from vendors who are under state procurement
contract, when the price is that price established by the contract awarded by
the state after competitive bidding pursuant to state code, or less.
      (b)   Purchases made from vendors who, within the past sixty (60) days,
have been under state procurement contract, when the price offered is the price
established by the former contract awarded by the state after competitive
bidding pursuant to state code, or less.
   (8)   Government Goods And Services: Those goods and services made available
by any federal, state or local unit of government, or association of
government, and acquired in compliance with the provisions of this chapter or
state code.
   (9)   Fringe Benefits: Purchases of services or benefits that are part of
any personnel fringe benefit agreements are authorized by the city council and
may be negotiated between the city manager and the service or benefit vendor.
   (10)   City Owned Concession Or Recreation Facility: Purchases or contracts
for supplies, materials or inventory to be used for resale at any city owned
and/or operated concession or recreation facility.
   (11)   Public Auction And Other Similar Circumstances: Supplies, materials
or equipment that can be purchased at any public auction, closeout sale,
bankruptcy sale or other similar sale, at a price below the market cost in the
community.
   (12)   Exchange Of Supplies, Material Or Equipment: Exchanges of supplies,
material or equipment between the city and any other entity.
   (13)   Utah Correctional Industries Division: Supplies, material or
equipment produced by the Utah correctional industries division. (Ord. 2006-27,
2006)
3.12.305: ADVERTISEMENT, REJECTION AND EXTENSION OF BIDS:
   (1)   Advertisement Of Bid:
      (a)   The department head shall provide the purchasing agent with an
appropriate advertisement or description of the item to be advertised so that
the purchasing agent may formulate a bid advertisement. The purchasing agent
shall then, with the concurrence of the city manager, place the advertisement
in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The request for bid
shall include:
         (i)   A description of the material, supplies, services, personal
property or construction in sufficient detail that prospective bidders should
know what their obligations will be, which description may be made either in
the advertisement itself or by reference to detailed plans and specifications
on file with the purchasing agent;
         (ii)   Deadline for bids to be received;
         (iii)   Time and place for the opening of the bids;
         (iv)   Notification of the city's requirements for a bidder's good
faith deposit, bid bond, or performance bond, as well as proof of liability
insurance and workers' compensation insurance;
         (v)   An announcement that the city may reject all bids, or any part
thereof;
         (vi)   Any other information upon which the bidder must rely in order
to be a responsible bidder.
      (b)   Contracts shall be awarded based on competitive sealed bidding,
except as otherwise provided herein.
      (c)   An invitation for bids shall be issued when a contract is to be
awarded by competitive sealed bidding. The invitation shall include a purchase
description and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the
procurement.
      (d)   Public notice of the invitation for bids shall be given within a
reasonable time prior to the date set forth therein for the opening of bids.
The notice may include publication in a newspaper of general circulation within
the city within a reasonable time prior to bid opening.
"Reasonable time" for purposes of this chapter, means that a notice of an
invitation for bids shall, prior to the acceptance of a bid, be published at
least once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks in one or more newspapers of
general circulation within the city.
      (e)   Bids shall be opened publicly at the time designated in the
invitation in the presence of one or more witnesses (including the purchasing
agent and the concerned department head when practical) at city hall, or other
place designated in the invitation for bids if use of the city hall is not
available or impracticable.
      (f)   The amount of each bid and any other relevant information specified
in the bid notice, together with the name of each bidder, shall be recorded by
the city recorder at the time the bids are opened. The record and each bid
shall be open to public inspection.
      (g)   Bids shall be unconditionally accepted without alteration or
correction, except as authorized in this chapter.
      (h)   Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the
invitation for bids, which may include criteria to determine acceptability such
as inspection, testing, quality, workmanship, delivery, and suitability for a
particular purpose. Those criteria that will affect the bid price and will be
considered in evaluation for award shall be objectively measurable. The
criteria may include discounts, transportation costs, and total or life cycle
cost. No criteria may be used in bid evaluations that are not set forth in the
invitation for bids.
      (i)   Correction or withdrawal of inadvertently erroneous bids before or
after award, or cancellation of awards or contracts based on such bid mistakes,
shall be permitted in accordance with rules and regulations set out in the bid
notice.
      (j)   After bid opening, no changes in bid prices or other provisions of
bids prejudicial to the interest of the city or fair competition shall be
permitted. Except as otherwise provided by this chapter or rules and
regulations set out in the bid notice, all decisions to permit the correction
or withdrawal of bids or to cancel awards or contracts based on bid mistakes
shall be supported by a written determination made by the city manager or city
council, depending on the value of the bid received, and in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter.
      (k)   The contract shall be awarded with reasonable promptness by written
notice to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder whose bid meets the
requirements and criteria set forth in the invitation for bids. In the event
all bids for a construction project exceed available budgeted funds as
certified by the city recorder and the lowest responsive and responsible bid
does not exceed such funds by more than five percent (5%), the city manager is
authorized, in situations where time or economic considerations preclude
resolicitation of bids of a reduced scope, to negotiate an adjustment of the
bid price, including changes in the bid requirements, with the lowest
responsive and responsible bidder, in order to bring the bid within the amount
of available funds.
      (l)   When it is considered impractical to initially prepare a purchase
description to support an award based on price, an invitation for bids may be
issued requesting the submission of unpriced offers to be followed by an
invitation for bids limited to those bidders whose offers have been qualified
under the criteria set forth in the first solicitation.
   (2)   Rejection Of Bids:
      (a)   An invitation for bids, a request for proposals, or other
solicitation may be canceled, or any or all bids or proposals may be rejected,
in whole or in part, specified in the solicitation, when it is in the best
interests of the city in accordance with rules and regulations set out in the
bid notice or invitation. The reasons for such rejections shall be made part of
the contract or bid file. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
      (b)   The city council shall have the authority to reject all bids, parts
of all bids or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services
included in the proposed contract, when the lowest responsible bid exceeds
available budgeted funds as certified by the city recorder, or when the public
interest will be served thereby and when permitted by law to do so. When all
bids exceed available budgeted funds and time or economic considerations
preclude resolicitation of work or purchase of a reduced scope or quantity, the
purchasing agent may negotiate an adjustment of the bid price, including
changes in the bid requirements, with the lowest responsible bidder, in order
to bring the low bid within the amount of available funds. (Ord. 2007-20, 2007)
   (3)   Extension Of Bids: The city manager may extend the time for opening of
bids, if in his/her opinion it is in the public interest to do so. Notice of
the extension shall be given to all prospective bidders by the purchasing agent
in such manner as is most practical under the circumstances. Such extension
shall not exceed ten (10) working days. No extension may be granted for the
purpose of qualifying a bid that was delivered after the time advertised for
the original opening.
   (4)   Late Bids: No bids shall be received or accepted at any time
subsequent to the time indicated in the announcement. Any bids delivered by
mail, or any other means, subsequent to the appointed time shall not be opened.
   (5)   Responsible Bidder: The city shall award contracts, which are required
to be let by competitive bidding under this chapter to the lowest responsible
bidder. The city may reject the lowest bid and accept the next lowest bid if
the city determines that the lowest bid was made by a bidder who is not
responsible.
      (a)   The city may consider any or all of the following when determining
whether a bidder is responsible:
         (i)   Whether the bid fully complies with the invitation for bids;
         (ii)   The bidder's financial responsibility;
         (iii)   The bidder's honesty and integrity;
         (iv)   Whether the bidder has the skill and business judgment to
complete the contract;
         (v)   The bidder's experience;
         (vi)   Whether the bidder has the facilities and equipment to complete
the contract;
         (vii)   The bidder's conduct under other contracts, regardless of
whether the contracts were with the city or with other parties;
         (viii)   The quality of the bidder's other work, regardless of whether
the work was performed for the city or for other parties; and
         (ix)   Any other matter bearing on the likelihood that the bidder will
promptly and efficiently perform the contract.
      (b)   If the city determines that the lowest bidder is not responsible,
the city shall notify the bidder in writing that it is rejecting the bidder's
bid. The notice shall also contain a short description of the reasons for the
rejection. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.306: BONDS OF BIDDERS MAY BE REQUIRED:
   (1)   Bidders may be required to supply deposits of good faith, or bonds
with sufficient sureties, in such amounts as shall be deemed adequate and
approved by the city manager or city council, as set out in the bid notice, not
only to ensure performance of the contract or purchase order in the time and
manner prescribed, but also to save, indemnify, and hold the city harmless
against losses, damages, claims, liabilities, judgments, costs, and expenses
which may accrue in consequence of granting the contract or purchase order.
   (2)   Before any contract for the construction, alteration or repair of any
public building, public work or public improvement of the city is awarded to
any person, that person shall furnish to the city such bonds as are required by
state code.
   (3)   Exceptions include repair and maintenance on city equipment and
property. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.307: CONTRACTS REQUIRED:
   (1)   A contract signed by both parties is required when:
      (a)   Personal property is acquired by means of lease, rental or
installment purchase;
      (b)   Personal or professional services are required by the city, except
where the services are to be performed at the vendor's place of business, or
where the services are for nonrepetitive repairs or maintenance, and where a
purchase order has been bid or negotiated to cover said services;
      (c)   Consultant services are to be acquired;
      (d)   Real estate or any interest therein is to be acquired except:
         (i)   When acquired pursuant to the power of eminent domain and entry
of a decree by a court of competent jurisdiction;
         (ii)   When acquired as a result of the filings and recording of a map
or plat as required by the city subdivision ordinance;
      (e)   The requesting office, department, agency or city council shall so
specify;
      (f)   The vendor requires that a contract other than a purchase order be
signed by the city; and
      (g)   Intergovernmental, interagency and service provider agreements
require participation by the city involving funding, performance or assumption
of liability or risk in any form.
   (2)   The following procedure should be followed for all contracts for
construction:
      (a)   Two (2) original copies of the contract document shall be prepared
with all required supplemental information attached, signed by the contractor,
and forwarded to the city recorder. Required attachments are:
         (i)   One hundred percent (100%) performance bond;
         (ii)   One hundred percent (100%) payment bond;
         (iii)   Certificate of liability insurance;
         (iv)   Certificate of workers' compensation insurance.
      (b)   The city recorder shall review the contract document and all
attachments.
      (c)   Contracts over twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) shall be
forwarded to the city attorney for review and approval.
      (d)   The city recorder shall submit the contract document with all
required attachments to the mayor for signature, and attest the mayor's
signature.
      (e)   Upon final contract approval, the city recorder shall return one
original and one copy of the signed contract to the appropriate department head
and retain the second original contract.
      (f)   The appropriate department head shall prepare the notice to proceed
for the contractor and submit a copy of the notice to proceed to the city
recorder for filing with the original contract.
      (g)   Upon completion of the project, the appropriate department head
shall prepare a notice of completion and submit the notice of completion to the
city recorder for filing with the original contract.
      (h)   No work may begin prior to final contract approval. (Ord. 2006-27,
2006)
PART 4. INSPECTION AND PAYMENT; FIXED ASSETS
3.12.401: INSPECTION OF MERCHANDISE RECEIVED:
   (1)   It shall be the responsibility of the department head or his designees
to immediately inspect all material, supplies, equipment and personal property
of any nature purchased pursuant to this chapter prior to the acceptance of the
delivery.
   (2)   The signature of the individual conducting the inspection shall be
required on all packing/delivery slips to designate that they have received and
inspected the merchandise.
   (3)   Damaged property or items not specified on the purchase order shall
not be accepted, and the nonconforming nature of the goods, together with the
reason for rejection thereof, shall be noted in writing upon the delivery
receipt. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.402: WHEN CHECKS MAY BE WRITTEN:
Checks may be written after proof of receipt or completion and an invoice for
the expenditure is received. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
3.12.403: FIXED ASSETS:
Whenever payment is made for an acquisition costing five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) or more, the director of finance shall forthwith record said
acquisition in the fixed asset inventory records of the city and shall cause a
property sticker to be placed upon said asset. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
PART 5. CHECKS AND BALANCES
3.12.501: SEPARATION OF CASH RECEIPTING AND ACCOUNTING RESPONSIBILITIES
REQUIRED:
Employees responsible for cash receipting shall not be involved in accounting
functions. Employees responsible for accounting functions shall not be involved
in cash receipting. (Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
PART 6. DISPOSAL OF CITY PROPERTY 1
   (Rep. by Ord. 2010-16, 2010)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 1 of this title.
PART 7. APPEALS
3.12.701: APPEALS:
   (1)   Any actual or prospective bidder, offeror or contractor who is
aggrieved in connection with the solicitation or award of a contract may appeal
to the city recorder. An appeal shall be submitted in writing within five (5)
working days after the aggrieved person knows or should have known of the
facts.
   (2)   The city recorder shall promptly issue a written decision regarding
any appeal, if it is not settled by a mutual agreement. The decision shall
state the reasons for the action taken and inform the protestor, contractor or
prospective contractor of the right to appeal to the city manager.
   (3)   The city manager shall be the final appeal on the city level.
   (4)   All further appeals shall be handled in accordance with state code.
(Ord. 2006-27, 2006)
