11.03.130: Perpetual Care Included
11.03.131: Perpetual Care Fund Created
11.03.132: Duties Of City Treasurer
11.03.133: Income From Fund
11.03.101: DEFINITIONS:
The following words or phrases shall have the following meanings unless the
context otherwise clearly requires:
LOT: Means and includes the partial lots or single graves in the city cemetery.
LOT OWNER OR PURCHASER AND GRAVE OWNER OR PURCHASER: The owner or purchaser of
burial privileges or the collateral right of use of any burial lot evidenced by
a deed or burial right for a described lot or by proved and recognized descent
or devise from the original owner.
PLOT: Each single gravesite within a lot. (Prior Code § 8-201)
11.03.102: CEMETERY DESIGNATED:
The city burial ground shall be known and designated by the name of Ivins City
cemetery. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.103: CHAPTER APPLICABILITY:
All cemeteries owned and/or maintained by the city, or which may hereafter be
acquired by the city, wherever situated, are declared subject to the provisions
of this chapter. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.104: CEMETERY SUPERINTENDENT; OFFICE CREATED:
There is created the position of cemetery superintendent. (Prior Code § 8-211)
11.03.105: CEMETERY SUPERINTENDENT DUTIES:
The cemetery superintendent shall be designated by the public works director
and shall have the general supervision and administration of the city cemetery,
including, but not limited to:
   (1)   Creating such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the
operation, maintenance, use and protection of the cemetery;
   (2)   Subdividing the cemetery into lots and gravesites;
   (3)   Maintaining a record of the location of the graves and preventing any
lot from being used beyond its capacity;
   (4)   Keeping in proper repair any enclosure around the cemetery and
preventing it being entered by animals and, so far as practical, preventing the
destruction or defacing of any tablet or marker placed or erected therein;
   (5)   Keeping a duplicate plat of the cemetery and, at the request of any
person wishing to purchase any of the lots or parts of lots, pointing out any
of the lots or parts of lots for sale; and upon disposal of any lots or part
thereof, after payment of the lot price has been received in the treasury,
issue a certificate of burial rights, which shall describe the lot or grave to
which the right to burial is granted. The certificate shall be signed by the
cemetery superintendent;
   (6)   Opening any graves in the cemetery upon application to him by any
person having the right to make such application and being responsible for
closing all graves;
   (7)   Removing floral pieces or displays left on any grave as deemed
necessary to the appearance of the cemetery, but such floral pieces or displays
shall not be removed sooner than three (3) days after original placement,
except in an emergency;
   (8)   Keeping the streets, alleys, walks and avenues in the cemetery in good
order and unobstructed;
   (9)   Erecting a suitable marker firmly set upon the northwest corner of
each lot with the number of the lot inscribed thereon and which location shall
be shown on the cemetery records. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.106: BURIAL REQUIREMENTS:
Before any deceased person is buried in the city cemetery, a permit properly
issued by the registrar of the registration district in which the death
occurred or, in the absence of such registrar, a permit duly issued by the
state division of health or other authorized person shall be required by the
cemetery superintendent. After burial, the cemetery superintendent shall
endorse upon the permit a description of the location where the deceased is
buried and shall enter all of the information contained in the permit in the
cemetery records. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.107: BURIAL PERMIT REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to bury the body of a deceased person in the city
cemetery without first obtaining a certificate of burial right for the lot used
or producing satisfactory evidence of a right to burial based on a properly
acquired certificate of burial right. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.108: REGISTRATION OF BURIALS:
Before any deceased person may be buried in the city cemetery, the relatives or
person having charge of the deceased shall provide the cemetery superintendent
with a written statement which shall be filed by the cemetery superintendent,
which statement shall contain, if known, information about the deceased
regarding his or her name, when and where born, the date and cause of death,
the name of the attending physician, date of burial, name of cemetery, and the
description of the location of the grave. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.109: BURIALS; DISINTERMENT:
It is a class B misdemeanor for any person to:
   (1)   Disinter any body buried in any cemetery, except under the direction
of the cemetery superintendent who shall, before disinterment, require a
written permission from both the city health officer and the owner of the lot
or his or her heirs, which written authorization shall be filed and preserved
in a record kept for such purposes;
   (2)   Disinter or remove the body of a person who has died from a contagious
disease within two (2) years after the date of burial, unless the body is
buried in a hermetically sealed casket or vault and is found to be incased at
the time of disinterment;
   (3)   Inter anything other than the remains of human bodies in the city
cemetery;
   (4)   Bury a body of any person within this city except in the city cemetery
or a private cemetery, unless special permission of the governing body under
such rules and regulations that it may prescribe. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.110: BURIAL OF INDIGENTS:
   (1)   The city council may by resolution designate a portion of the city
cemetery to the burial of indigents. Whenever it is made to appear to the mayor
by proof submitted to him by the cemetery superintendent that any person who
has died does not have the estate sufficient to pay the purchase price of a lot
in the cemetery, and that the nearest relative or representative of such
deceased person desires to have the body of such deceased interred in the
cemetery, the mayor may grant burial space for such deceased person at the
request made to him by the cemetery superintendent.
   (2)   The mayor shall communicate his decision to the cemetery
superintendent. The mayor shall give report of his decision, whether
affirmative or negative, to the governing body at its next regular meeting. All
strangers without funds or other persons who may die in the city may be granted
the privilege granted herein. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.111: BURIAL; INFANTS AND CHILDREN:
   (1)   Lot 83 of the city cemetery as shown on the plat thereof, shall be set
aside for small graves for the interment of infants or other young people
appropriate to the size of the small graves. Such lot currently consists of
eight (8) plots and shall be further divided into sixteen (16) plots.
   (2)   The fees applicable to such plots shall be specified in the
consolidated fee schedule.
   (3)   The cemetery superintendent is directed to make these changes in the
records of the city and to make available lot 83 for such interments. (Ord.
2006-18, 2006)
11.03.112: VAULTS REQUIRED:
   (1)   It is unlawful for any person to be buried in the cemetery unless the
casket shall be placed in a vault made of concrete, propylene, fiberglass,
steel or brick lined or of such other material approved by the city council,
substantially constructed and covered with a similar durable material.
   (2)   No wood shall be used as a permanent part of the construction of any
part of the vault. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006; amd. Ord. 2023-30, 12-21-2023)
11.03.113: RELIGIOUS AND FRATERNAL ORGANIZATIONS:
The city may contract with religious and fraternal organizations to designate a
reasonable portion of the cemetery in which burials may be restricted to
members of such religious and fraternal organizations and their families. (Ord.
2006-18, 2006)
11.03.114: SALE SUBJECT TO RULES:
Every lot or single grave sold is subject to rules and regulations that have
been or may be adopted. The rules and regulations shall be subject to such
changes as are found necessary for the protection of lot owners, the remains of
the dead and the preservation of the cemetery. (Prior Code § 8-227)
11.03.115: CARE AND UPKEEP BY CITY:
The city reserves the right to enter upon any grave and perform all work
necessary for the care and upkeep of all lots and graves in its cemeteries.
(Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.116: DISINTERMENT ERRORS; CITY NOT LIABLE:
Under no circumstances will the city assume responsibilities for errors in
opening graves. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.117: TRAFFIC RULES:
   (1)   The provisions of the city traffic ordinances relative to the
operation of vehicles and conduct of pedestrians shall be in effect in the
cemetery, except as herein otherwise modified by this chapter.
   (2)   It is unlawful for any person to ride or drive within the city
cemetery at a speed greater than ten (10) miles per hour. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.118: CHILDREN TO BE SUPERVISED:
Children under the age of twelve (12) years shall not be allowed in cemeteries
unless accompanied by their parents or other adults. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.119: ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
No animal shall be allowed in any cemetery except in the confines of a vehicle
and must be at all times retained within the confines of the vehicle while the
vehicle remains in the cemetery. (Prior Code § 8-232)
11.03.120: DECORUM:
Cemetery grounds are sacredly devoted to the interment and repose of the dead.
Strict observance of decorum due such a place shall be required of all persons.
(Prior Code § 8-233)
11.03.121: INJURY TO CEMETERY PROPERTY PROHIBITED:
   (1)   It is a class B misdemeanor for any person to tie or attempt to tie
any horse, animal or motor vehicle to any monument, gravestone, tablet, marker,
tree, shrub, fence or enclosure on the premises of the cemetery for the purpose
of injuring, defacing or attempting the removal of same.
   (2)   It is an infraction for any person to injure, deface, break, destroy
or remove any headstone, tombstone, monument, tree, shrub, or any other
property in the cemetery. (Prior Code § 8-234)
11.03.122: LANDSCAPING BY PRIVATE PERSONS:
Except as provided by the cemetery rules and regulations, it is unlawful for
any person to erect or maintain any fence, corner post, coping or boundary of
any kind, to plant any vegetation upon any lot or lots, street, alley or walk
in the cemetery, or to grade the ground or land thereof. The cemetery
superintendent shall, whenever required, furnish the true lines of any lots
according to official survey, shall prevent and prohibit any markings of the
same except by official landmarks, and shall prevent and prohibit any grading
thereof that might destroy or interfere with the general slope of the land.
(Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.123: PLACEMENT OF MARKERS:
It is unlawful for any person to erect, place or cause to be placed any marker
or monument on any lot in the cemetery in violation of the rules and
regulations promulgated by the city council regarding the placement,
construction and design of all such markers. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.124: COLLECTION OF FEES:
The cemetery superintendent shall verify that all required fees have been paid
in advance to the city treasurer for the opening and closing of graves or other
services, which shall include, but not be limited to, properly disinterring
bodies and properly restoring the earth and grounds, recording each burial,
disinterment or removal, and raised monument privileges. The fee shall be such
amounts as are determined by the governing body from time to time by
resolution. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.125: FEE FOR OPENING GRAVE:
   (1)   No grave shall be opened in the city cemetery until payment of a fee
for the labor and expense in so opening the grave shall be paid.
   (2)   The presentation of a receipt from the city recorder or other
authorized person when presented to the cemetery superintendent shall be
authority to open a grave for the burial of a deceased person. However, upon a
contract being entered into between any mortician and the city wherein the
mortician agrees to be responsible and liable for fees for the opening of a
grave, and wherein that mortician will be personally liable for such fees and
for perpetual care payments, the city recorder or other authorized person may
give the cemetery superintendent authority to open graves without the
presentation of a receipt from the city recorder or other authorized person.
(Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.126: PURCHASE PRICE AND FEES:
The city council shall from time to time by resolution fix the size of lots,
the price at which burial rights shall be sold and the fees which shall be
charged for the various cemetery services to be provided. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.127: SALE OF LOTS:
   (1)   The cemetery superintendent is authorized to sell the use of lots in
the city cemetery for burial purposes only and to collect all sums arising from
the sale. The cemetery superintendent shall keep a complete record of all
sales, which record shall describe the location of the lot purchased and the
price paid therefor. The cemetery superintendent shall deliver to each
purchaser a certificate of ownership of burial right for each lot purchased,
which certificate shall, among other things, describe the location of the lot
and the purchase price. In the event of an installment sale, the certificate
shall not issue or be delivered to the purchaser until the entire purchase
price for the lot, together with perpetual care, has been paid in full.
   (2)   A certificate and rights to burial shall be exempt from execution,
taxation or assessment for care and maintenance from and after full payment of
the purchase price. Payments pursuant to this section shall not be construed to
be in payment for cemetery services other than perpetual care or prepaid
maintenance.
   (3)   Perpetual care shall be deemed to include the filling of the grave,
the placing of topsoil upon the grave, seeding the grave with grass and
watering and cutting the grass. No other services are included.
   (4)   No other improvements, changes or service, except perpetual care,
shall be made on any lot without the certificate holder or his heirs first
submitting to, and receiving from the cemetery superintendent, written approval
for such improvements, changes or services, which improvements, changes or
services shall be subject to the rules and regulations. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.128: RESTRICTIONS OF RESALE:
   (1)   It is unlawful for any person to sell a cemetery plot upon the
promise, representation or inducement of resale at a financial profit. A
violation of this section is a misdemeanor and each violation shall constitute
a separate offense.
   (2)   Whenever a certificate to burial rights or lots reverts to the city,
as provided for in this chapter, or becomes vested in the city for any reason,
before new certificates are issued, the original certificate shall be cancelled
or an assignment given, and the record shall be so changed.
   (3)   The certificates shall be issued and signed by the cemetery
superintendent. All lots or parts of lots, as provided in this section,
together with all improvements, shall be exempt from execution and from
taxation and assessment for care and maintenance charges from and after said
payment. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.129: CONTRACTING FOR PERPETUAL CARE:
No grave shall be hereafter opened in the city cemetery until perpetual care
upon the plot where the grave is to be opened shall have been paid for in full.
(Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.130: PERPETUAL CARE INCLUDED:
The perpetual care that the city agrees to give shall consist of care of the
cemetery generally, and shall include, but is not limited to, mowing of all
lots and graves at reasonable intervals, resodding, seeding, and filling in
sunken graves, sodding the surface of the graves to lot level, removing dead
flowers and trimming trees and shrubbery when necessary, raking and cleaning
the lots and straightening of tilting stones or markers, but shall not include
repairing or replacing markers or memorial structures of any nature, except
when the need for repair or replacement is directly caused by the city. (Ord.
2006-18, 2006)
11.03.131: PERPETUAL CARE FUND CREATED:
   (1)   There is established a perpetual care fund according to the laws of
the state and this chapter. All funds received from the sale of perpetual care
services shall be placed in a special perpetual care fund, invested in
compliance with the laws of the state and used for the purposes herein
provided.
   (2)   The income from the perpetual care fund shall be used to pay the
upkeep and development of the cemetery. The city may borrow from the fund from
time to time, but any funds borrowed shall be repaid to the fund with interest
thereon at the prevailing rate paid by the city to borrow funds from commercial
lenders.
   (3)   If the city borrows from the fund, it shall pay into a fund for the
operation of the cemeteries the interest accrued upon money annually. Should it
be found that the interest returned upon the perpetual care funds shall be more
than is required to pay for the operation and upkeep of the city cemetery, then
the surplus shall be added to the principal amount of the perpetual care fund
herein created, and shall be so handled until changed by resolution to provide
for the use of such accumulated interest. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.132: DUTIES OF CITY TREASURER:
It is the duty of the city treasurer to keep an accurate record of the
perpetual care trust fund account, including investments, to see that the
principal portion thereof is properly invested in accordance with resolutions
of the city council and the laws of the state. (Ord. 2006-18, 2006)
11.03.133: INCOME FROM FUND:
All income from investments held in the perpetual care fund shall be credited
to the cemetery maintenance fund for use in providing the perpetual care as
required herein. (Prior Code § 8-274)
CHAPTER 4
PARKS
SECTION:
Part 1. Rules And Regulations
11.04.101: Rules And Regulations
11.04.102: Permits; Park/Pavilion Reservations
11.04.103: Penalty
Part 2. Concessions
11.04.201: Concessions
11.04.202: Penalty
PART 1. RULES AND REGULATIONS
11.04.101: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   (1)   Alcoholic Beverages, Drugs Or Gambling: The sale, consumption or
possession of alcoholic beverages and/or controlled substances, as well as
gambling of any kind, are prohibited in any and all city parks and recreation
facilities and areas.
   (2)   Camping Or Sleeping Overnight: Camping or sleeping overnight in city
parks is prohibited without advance written permission from the parks and
recreation department.
   (3)   Reserved.
   (4)   Domestic Animal Restrictions: Horses, cattle, livestock and domestic
animals of any kind are prohibited in any city park, except a cat or a dog on a
leash and under the control of a person. Parks designated by the city as
wilderness parks are exempted from application of this section. It is unlawful
for the owner of an animal to permit the animal to defecate upon a public park
unless the owner removes and properly disposes of all animal waste that may
result.
   (5)   Encroachment Of Park Lands: No person shall willingly encroach upon
lands administered by the parks and recreation department.
   (6)   Entertainment And Similar Activities: No entertainment, demonstration,
exhibition, meeting, concert or tournament, whether public or private, shall be
given in any city park without having first obtained a permit therefor from the
parks and recreation department at least fourteen (14) days prior to usage.
   (7)   Fireworks And Explosives: No person shall discharge or set off in any
city parks, or recreation facilities or areas, any firecrackers, rockets or
other fireworks or explosives, except as may be specifically and expressly
permitted and allowed in writing by the city council.
   (8)   Glass Bottles: No person shall bring onto or possess glass bottles on
any city park or recreational area.
   (9)   Large Groups: No group of twenty five (25) or more persons shall use a
city park area without first obtaining a permit therefor from the parks and
recreation department at least seven (7) days prior to usage. Group usage shall
be limited to designated areas. No person shall use loudspeakers, amplifiers or
public address systems in a park without written permission from the parks and
recreation department.
   (10)   League Or Tournament Games; Permit Required: Permits for playing
league or tournament games on city park fields or courts shall be secured from
the parks and recreation department on a first come, first served basis. A
valid permit shall be displayed upon request in order to avoid conflicts in the
use of facilities. Failure by park users to honor a valid permit is unlawful
and may result in the denial of future permits to use the facilities.
   (11)   Littering Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to cause or allow any
foreign material, papers, bottles, cans, rags or discarded articles of any
substantial kind or nature to be left in any city park.
   (12)   Motor Vehicles: No person shall ride in or drive any motor vehicle
(including both on road and off road vehicles, motorized scooters and
minimotorcycles), which is self- propelled upon any city park land, except upon
the roads and parking areas. It is prohibited for any person to commit any act,
by use or operation, of any motor vehicle on any city park land, which, if
committed upon a public highway or street in the state, would be prohibited and
unlawful. Speed limits within all parks shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour
unless otherwise posted. No one shall test or repair any vehicle or mechanical
device in any city park, except any vehicle, which may become disabled while at
the park.
   (13)   Nighttime Use: No persons are permitted in any city park during the
hours of darkness, except in those lighted areas designated for extended use
activities or unless written permission is obtained from the parks and
recreation department. All ball diamond and tennis court lighting shall be
turned off by eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. The city reserves the right to lock
any gate, chain or door offering access to any park, facility or building in
order to restrict nighttime usage thereof.
   (14)   Nuisance: It shall be a nuisance and unlawful for any person to use
threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language, to commit any obscene or
indecent act, to fight or to create a public disturbance, or to skateboard or
in-line skate outside designated areas, or to be under the influence of alcohol
or drugs, or to engage in any activity that threatens the safety or well being
of other persons, or to otherwise disturb the peace of park users by begging,
soliciting, making undue noise, or engaging in disruptive activities in any
city park.
   (15)   Open Fires: No person shall make or kindle any open fire in any city
park, except in fireplaces and/or grills provided for this purpose or in
private portable commercially manufactured grills or grills approved safe by
the parks and recreation department. Generally, the use of grills provided for
public use shall be on a first come, first served basis; however, the use of
any grills associated with the use of a park pavilion shall be included with
the reservation of the pavilion.
   (16)   Parking: Parking shall only be in designated parking areas, but in no
event overnight without written permission from the parks and recreation
department. Abandoned vehicles, including vehicles left in the park overnight,
shall be towed at the owner's expense.
   (17)   Refusal To Leave: It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to
leave any park if, after having violated any law or written rule or regulation
of the city concerning conduct in city parks, he or she has been ordered to
leave by a city employee.
   (18)   Signs And Advertising: No person shall, without written permission of
the parks and recreation department, erect, paint, paste or otherwise affix or
distribute any signs, advertisements or circulars on any city park property.
The sale of anything or the solicitation of funds or donations within any city
park is prohibited, except upon written permission of the parks and recreation
department.
   (19)   Teaching In Parks: No person or group may utilize any city park area
or facility for the purpose of teaching an individual or group any recreational
skill for personal profit or financial gain without written permission of the
parks and recreation department.
   (20)   Temporary Closure: The mayor or his designee may temporarily close or
curtail activities upon any city park lands or waters, or any portions thereof,
when it has been deemed to be in the best interest of public safety, conduct,
health or order.
   (21)   Trapping Or Injuring Animals: No person, other than public safety
personnel, shall, in any city park, set a trap or snare or kill, shoot, injure,
annoy, disturb or poison any animal or injure or destroy any nest.
   (22)   Vandalism; Dumping: It shall be unlawful for any person to scratch,
cut, break, move, take or otherwise injure, destroy or deface any restroom,
trees, shrubs, plants, turf, rock, or any building, fence, bridge, sign or
other structure, or to in any way foul or pollute any fountain, water feature,
spring, stream, pond or lake, or to leave waste items or rubbish of any kind,
or to commit any other act of vandalism to public or private property in any
city park. No person shall dump any earth, rubbish or other substance or
material in or upon any city park without written permission from the parks and
recreation department.
   (23)   Fire Lake Park Swim Area At Ivins Reservoir: In addition to the above
rules and regulations applicable to city parks in general, the following shall
be expressly prohibited at the swim area at Fire Lake Park at Ivins Reservoir
(defined as the causeway, the approximately 4 acre swim area, surrounding beach
areas and other improved areas): alcohol; glass bottles/containers; motorized
watercraft; motorized vehicles, including all-terrain vehicles; dogs and other
pets; fires; fireworks; and littering. Generally, Fire Lake Park swim area
hours are from dawn to dusk. The park is closed to the public during
nondaylight hours. It shall be illegal for any members of the public to be at
the park between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. and any vehicles remaining in the parking area during those hours shall be
subject to citation and/or towing at the vehicle owner's expense. (Ord. 2016-
14, 2016)
11.04.102: PERMITS; PARK/PAVILION RESERVATIONS:
The director of the parks and recreation department shall establish policies
and procedures outlining the requirements for obtaining any permits required by
this chapter and for reserving a park or pavilion. (Ord. 2005-33, 2005)
11.04.103: PENALTY:
Any persons violating any of the foregoing rules and regulations, other than
vandalism which shall be prosecuted under provisions for offenses against
property, shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor. Each violation shall be a
separate offense. (Ord. 2005-33, 2005)
PART 2. CONCESSIONS
11.04.201: CONCESSIONS:
   (1)   Concessions In City Parks: The operation of any and all concessions to
sell or rent any items (such as equipment, food, etc.) in any park or on any
other property owned by the city shall be governed by the provisions of this
section. All concessions shall also comply with any other applicable state or
local laws, including licensing requirements, if applicable.
   (2)   Concession Agreement: The privilege to operate a concession shall be
granted by agreement between the city and the concessionaire. The privilege to
operate a concession shall be determined on a competitive basis with service
clubs being given priority consideration. The concession agreement may be for
such period of time as agreed upon by the city and the concessionaire. The
parks and recreation department shall have the right to review the services
provided by the concessionaire at any time and to revoke the privilege to
operate the concession if it is determined that the concessionaire is not
abiding by the terms of the agreement or is not providing adequate service to
the public. The parks and recreation department director is authorized to
receive concession proposals and approve concession agreements in accordance
with the provisions of this section.
   (3)   Concession Structures:
      (a)   Permanent concessions structures shall not be allowed on city
property unless they are owned by the city. The city may enter into a long term
lease agreement of a city owned concession structure.
      (b)   Temporary concession stands shall be limited to vehicles, trailers
or mobile units approved by the parks and recreation director. These stands
shall be provided and satisfactorily maintained by the concessionaire.
   (4)   Liability Insurance Required: The concessionaire shall file with the
city recorder proof of liability insurance in a minimum amount acceptable to
the parks and recreation director. In addition, a waiver which holds the city
harmless from the acts or omissions of the concessionaire shall also be filed
with the city recorder.
   (5)   Care Of Concession Area: The concessionaire is to provide regular
service and cleanup of the designated areas as set forth in the concession
agreement.
   (6)   Fees For Concessions: The city reserves the right to charge a
percentage of concession revenues as a fee to help offset the costs of city
sponsored recreation programs and property maintenance. (Ord. 2005-33, 2005)
11.04.202: PENALTY:
Any person who operates any unauthorized concession in city parks or facilities
is guilty of a class C misdemeanor. (Ord. 2005-33, 2005)
