feet in any dimension. Grass shall not be within 10 feet of a roadway.
      (b)   Landscape and irrigation installers shall follow the plans that
have been signed and approved by the city.
      (c)   Each project shall propose and follow an approved Planting Plan
that has a minimum of twenty percent (20%) vegetative cover (based on the
American Society of Landscape Architects “Landscape Architecture Documentation
Standards: Principles, Guidelines and Best Practices”) of a landscaped area
with water-efficient shade trees (however, fruit and nut trees are allowed) and
bushes adequate in number and configuration to visually enhance the project,
prevent heat islands, and prevent soil erosion.
      (d)   If secondary irrigation water is available, each project shall
connect to the system for all outdoor water use. A city may make minor
exceptions, allowing use of treated water for outdoor plantings in small
beautification areas, in its sole discretion.
   (2)   Required Documentation:
      (a)   Landscape Documentation Package: A copy of a Landscape
Documentation Package shall be submitted to and approved by the city prior to
the issue of any building permit. A copy of the approved Landscape
Documentation Package shall be provided to the property owner or site manager.
The Landscape Documentation Package shall be prepared by a landscape designer
or a professional landscape architect (PLA).
   (3)   Misting systems are permitted from May through September when
temperatures exceed 90 degrees. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
PART 6. LANDSCAPE AND IRRIGATION DESIGN STANDARDS FOR ALL NEW DEVELOPMENT IN
ANY ZONE
14.11.601: GENERAL:
Landscape and irrigation design standards for all new development in any zone
except new construction and development within a resort which will be subject
to the requirements of Chapter 7. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
14.11.602: PLANT SELECTION AND MAINTENANCE:
Plants shall be well-suited to the microclimate and soil conditions at the
project site. Native, locally adaptable, and environmentally sustainable plants
are acceptable. See the Washington County Water Conservancy District’s
recommended plant list on wcwcd.org. Plants with similar water needs shall be
grouped together as much as possible into hydrozones for efficient irrigation.
Invasive plant species as identified by the city shall not be planted.
   (1)   Areas with slopes greater than ten percent (10%) shall be landscaped
with deep-rooting, water-conserving plants that do not include grass.
   (2)   Park strips and landscape buffers shall be landscaped with water-
conserving plants and/or mulch that do not include grass.
   (3)   Landscaping shall be maintained in a live and thriving condition, with
consideration for normal growth and water needs; and fertilized, mowed,
trimmed, edged, mulched and free from weeds, dead plants, litter, refuse, or
debris in compliance with regionally accepted horticultural practice and city
ordinances. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.603: TREE SELECTION:
Tree species shall be selected based on growth characteristics and site
conditions, including available space, overhead clearance, soil conditions,
exposure, and desired color and appearance. Trees shall be suited for water-
efficient landscapes; however, fruit and nut trees are allowed. Trees shall be
selected and planted in accordance with the following city guidance:
   (1)   Broad canopy trees are recommended where shade or screening of tall
objects is desired;
   (2)   Low-growing trees are recommended for spaces under utility wires;
   (3)   Select trees from which lower branches will be trimmed to maintain a
healthy growth habit where visual clearance and natural surveillance is a
concern;
   (4)   Narrow or columnar trees are recommended for small spaces, or where
awnings or other building features limit growth, or where greater visibility is
desired between buildings and the street for natural surveillance;
   (5)   Tree placement shall provide canopy cover (shade) and avoid conflicts
with existing trees, retaining walls, above and below ground utilities,
lighting, and other obstructions. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
14.11.604: IRRIGATION DESIGN STANDARDS:
   (1)   Pressure Regulation. A pressure regulating valve shall be installed by
the builder or developer, and maintained by the owner, if the static service
pressure exceeds ninety (90) pounds per square inch (psi). The pressure-
regulating valve shall be located between the meter and the first point of
water use, or first point of division in the pipe, and shall be set at the
manufacturer’s recommended pressure for the sprinklers.
   (2)    Irrigation Controller. It is required that landscaped areas use a
WaterSense labeled smart irrigation controller, or controllers that are at
least as water-efficient, which automatically adjusts the frequency and/or
duration of irrigation events in response to changing weather conditions. All
controllers shall be equipped with automatic rain delay or rain shut-off
capabilities and have memory retention capability to retain pre-programmed
irrigation schedules. Sites are not exempt from water waste prohibitions.
   (3)   Low-volume irrigation equipment (i.e., drip emitters, bubblers) shall
be provided for each tree.
   (4)   Drip irrigation shall be used to irrigate plants in non-grass areas.
Sprinkler lines and drip lines shall not be connected to the same valve.
   (5)   High conservation efficiency spray nozzles are required for sprinkler
applications.
   (6)   Sprinkler heads shall have matched precipitation rates with each
control valve circuit.
   (7)   Filters, pressure regulators, flush end assemblies, and emitters rated
for 20 gallons per hour or less shall be provided for drip irrigation lines.
   (8)   Landscape watering with potable (treated) water is prohibited based on
Ivins City requirements, which are currently from eight o’clock (8:00) a.m. to
eight o’clock (8:00) p.m., from June 1 to September 1, to maximize irrigation
efficiency.
   (9)   Water waste is prohibited. Waste includes overwatering, irrigating
during a precipitation event, water that sprays or flows off your property,
failure to comply with drought restrictions and/or a failure to repair
irrigation system leaks and/or malfunctions in a timely manner.
   (10)   Program valves for multiple repeat cycles are required to reduce
runoff on slopes and for soils with slow infiltration rates.
   (11)   To the extent possible, spray irrigation should be free from
obstructions such as trees, signs, posts, enclosures, etc. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-
2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.605: MULCH REQUIRED:
   (1)   All Planting Beds must have mulch upon the soil surface with
exceptions for areas being restored to appear as native desert. (Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
14.11.606: METERING:
   (1)   All attached and detached single-family dwelling units with ground
floor square footage shall be separately metered, submetered, or equipped with
alternative technology capable of tracking the water use of the individual
unit.
   (2)   All non-single family residential projects require separate meters for
outdoor water use when irrigating more than 5,000 square feet. (Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
PART 7. RESORT DEVELOPMENT WATER EFFICIENCY STANDARDS
14.11.701: GENERAL:
The provisions of this Chapter are applicable to all new construction, and new
development within any resort.
Specific provisions of this Chapter can be waived by the City if a hydrologist,
water use engineer, landscape architect that is licensed in the State of Utah,
or similarly qualified expert approved by the City provides a statement and
supporting documentation showing that the design meets or exceeds all the water
conservation measures and goals in this chapter. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd.
Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.702: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
   (1)   Within the resort development, new single-family, two-family (twin
home/duplex), and three-family (triplex) residential dwellings 1,200 square
feet or greater shall install hot water recirculation systems.
   (2)   All water fixtures shall be WaterSense labeled fixtures, or fixtures
that are at least as water-efficient, including, but not limited to faucets,
showerheads, toilets, and urinals. All fixtures shall meet or exceed the water
conservation requirements specified by Utah Code.
   (3)   All appliances shall be Energy Star qualified appliances, or
appliances that are at least as energy-efficient.
   (4)   Exterior, decorative water features must have recirculating pumps. The
feature is also limited to 25 square feet per parcel and is limited to the
parcel. This excludes any area of a golf course and water features within a
golf course. Exterior decorative water features shall not be used as entry
features to the resort development. The allowed amount of grass will be reduced
based on the capacity of the water feature in gallons using one gallon equals
two square foot of grass.
   (5)   The square footage of any uncovered pool will be counted towards the
allowed amount of grass. A pool is considered uncovered if it does not have a
UL approved cover that is electrically operated.” Twenty-five percent (25%) of
the square footage of any pool with a UL approved electrically operated cover,
or indoor pools, will be counted towards the allowed amount of grass.
   (6)   Except for hotel rooms, all residential and nonresidential units shall
be separately metered, submetered, or equipped with alternative technology
capable of tracking the water use of the individual unit, and the information
shall be made available to the individual unit. All nonresidential projects
require separate water meters for all outdoor water usage, including
landscaping. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.703: LANDSCAPE STANDARDS:
   (1)   Grass area must not exceed eight percent (8%) of the square footage of
the total resort development. This excludes the grass area of any golf course.
Grass areas shall have a minimum width of eight (8) feet in any dimension.
Grass shall not be within 10 feet of a roadway.
   (2)   Grass is not permitted outside of an active recreation area. Grass is
prohibited in park strips, landscape buffers, and on any slope that exceeds ten
percent (10%); and
   (3)   Any lot in any zone which is larger than one-half (1/2) acre must use
secondary irrigation where available to irrigate any agricultural,
horticultural, or gardening uses which are permitted in the applicable zone.
   (4)   Landscape and irrigation installers shall follow the plans that have
been signed and approved by the city.
   (5)   Each project shall propose and follow an approved Planting Plan that
has a minimum of twenty percent (20%) vegetative cover (cover based on
landscaping standards at maturity) of a landscaped area with water-efficient
shade trees (however, fruit and nut trees are allowed) and bushes adequate in
number and configuration to visually enhance the project, prevent heat islands,
and prevent soil erosion.
   (6)   If secondary irrigation water is available, each project shall connect
to the system for all outdoor water use. A city may make minor exceptions,
allowing use of treated water for outdoor plantings in small beautification
areas, in its sole discretion.
   (7)   Golf courses using district or city supplied water shall have a
separate meter for irrigation.
   (8)   All golf courses, without regard to date of construction, shall be
required to submit and follow a water budget and identify water conservation
measures for regular city and water provider review.
   (9)   Misting systems are permitted from May through September when
temperatures exceed 90 degrees. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
14.11.704: REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION:
Landscape Documentation Package: A copy of a Landscape Documentation Package
shall be submitted to and approved by the city prior to the issue of any
building permit. A copy of the approved Landscape Documentation Package shall
be provided to the property owner or site manager. The Landscape Documentation
Package shall be prepared by a professional landscape architect (PLA) and
installed and maintained according to industry standards. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-
2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.705: PLANT SELECTION:
Plants shall be well-suited to the microclimate and soil conditions at the
project site. Native, locally adaptable and environmentally sustainable plants
are acceptable. See the Washington County Water Conservancy District’s
recommended plant list on wcwcd.org. Plants with similar water needs shall be
grouped together as much as possible into hydrozones for efficient irrigation.
Invasive plant species as identified by the city shall not be planted.
   (1)   Areas with slopes greater than 10% shall be landscaped with deep-
rooting, water-conserving plants that do not include grass.
   (2)   Park strips and landscape buffers shall be landscaped with water-
conserving plants and/or mulch that do not include grass. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-
2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.706: TREE SELECTION:
Tree species shall be selected based on growth characteristics and site
conditions, including available space, overhead clearance, soil conditions,
exposure, and desired color and appearance. Trees shall be suited for water-
efficient landscapes (however, fruit and nut trees are allowed). Trees shall be
selected and planted in accordance with the following city guidance:
   (1)   Broad canopy trees are recommended where shade or screening of tall
objects is desired;
   (2)   Low-growing trees are recommended for spaces under utility wires;
   (3)   Select trees from which lower branches will be trimmed to maintain a
healthy growth habit where visual clearance and natural surveillance is a
concern;
   (4)   Narrow or columnar trees are recommended for small spaces, or where
awnings or other building features limit growth, or where greater visibility is
desired between buildings and the street for natural surveillance;
   (5)   Tree placement shall provide canopy cover (shade) and avoid conflicts
with existing trees, retaining walls, above and below ground utilities,
lighting, and other obstructions, and be placed to protect view corridors and
viewsheds; and
Trees shall be irrigated on a separate hydrozone as needed for efficient
irrigation and allow for watering under water-shortage conditions when other
plant material may not be watered due to drought conditions. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-
2-2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.707: IRRIGATION DESIGN STANDARDS:
   (1)   Pressure Regulation. A pressure regulating valve shall be installed by
the builder or developer, and maintained by the owner, if the static service
pressure exceeds ninety (90) pounds per square inch (psi). The pressure-
regulating valve shall be located between the meter and the first point of
water use, or first point of division in the pipe, and shall be set at the
manufacturer’s recommended pressure for the sprinklers.
   (2)   Irrigation Controller. It is required that landscaped areas use a
WaterSense labeled smart irrigation controllers or controllers that are at
least as water-efficient, which automatically adjusts the frequency and/or
duration of irrigation events in response to changing weather conditions. All
controllers shall be equipped with automatic rain delay or rain shut-off
capabilities and have memory retention capability to retain pre-programmed
irrigation schedules. Sites are not exempt from water waste prohibitions.
   (3)   Low-volume irrigation equipment (i.e., drip emitters, bubblers) shall
be provided for each tree.
   (4)   Drip irrigation shall be used to irrigate plants in non-grass areas.
Sprinkler lines and drip lines shall not be connected to the same valve.
   (5)   High conservation efficiency spray nozzles are required for sprinkler
applications.
   (6)   Sprinkler heads shall have matched precipitation rates with each
control valve circuit.
   (7)   Filters, pressure regulators, flush end assemblies, and emitters rated
for 20 gallons per hour or less shall be provided for drip irrigation lines.
   (8)   Landscape watering with potable (treated) water is prohibited based on
Ivins city requirements, which are currently from eight o’clock (8:00) a.m. to
eight o’clock (8:00) p.m., from June 1 to September 1, to maximize irrigation
efficiency.
   (9)   Water waste is prohibited. Waste includes overwatering, irrigating
during a precipitation event, water that sprays or flows off your property,
failure to comply with drought restrictions and/or a failure to repair
irrigation system leaks and/or malfunctions in a timely manner.
   (10)   Program valves for multiple repeat cycles are required to reduce
runoff on slopes and for soils with slow infiltration rates.
   (11)   To the extent possible, spray irrigation should be free from
obstructions such as trees, signs, posts, enclosures, etc. (Ord. 2022-06, 6-2-
2022; amd. Ord. 2023-21, 2023)
14.11.708: MULCH REQUIRED:
   (1)   All Planting Beds must have mulch upon the soil surface with
exceptions for areas being restored to appear as native desert. (Ord. 2023-21,
2023)
TITLE 15
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
15.01.101: Overview
15.01.102: Short Title
15.01.103: Statement Of Purpose
15.01.104: Interpretation
15.01.105: Coordination With Other Documents
15.01.106: Orderly Development Required
15.01.107: Compliance Required
15.01.108: Amendments
15.01.109: Public Notice
15.01.110: Penalties For Violation
15.01.111: Appeals
15.01.101: OVERVIEW:
The activities related to the use, sale and development of land have been
determined by federal and state law to be in the public interest for local
government to oversee and regulate in order to bring about the safe and orderly
creation (and maintenance) of communities. These activities may include
subdividing land into lots for sale, building structures, constructing roads,
constructing trails and/or installing utilities. In order to effectively
regulate these activities, communities are empowered to establish review and
permitting processes. This title contains the review and permitting processes
related to land development activities in the city. This title contains the
review and permitting processes for conventional subdivision developments and
phased subdivisions. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.01.102: SHORT TITLE:
This title shall be known as the IVINS CITY SUBDIVISION ORDINANCE, also known
as title 15 of this code, and is herein referred to as "this title". (Ord.
2006-02, 2006)
15.01.103: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
This title, and any rules, regulations and specifications hereafter adopted,
are adopted for the following purposes:
   (1)   To promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare;
   (2)   To promote cohesive, orderly growth and development by efficient
layout and use of building lots, roads and public services and utilities;
   (3)   To encourage and promote the conservation, wise use and management of
natural resources in order to preserve the integrity, stability and beauty of
the community and value of the land;
   (4)   To maintain and enhance property values;
   (5)   To minimize conflict among the uses of lands and buildings;
   (6)   To implement the goals and objectives of the city general plan;
   (7)   To implement the goals and objectives of the city design guidelines
and standard specifications for design and construction;
   (8)   To inform the public of the requirements and conditions necessary to
obtain approvals and permits to change or create property boundaries (subdivide
land);
   (9)   To preserve the natural beauty of the city and preserve the natural,
cultural and historic features and enhance the quality of life in the city;
   (10)   To minimize traffic congestion and enhance mobility;
   (11)   To encourage efficiencies in public services and promote a
sustainable community;
   (12)   To protect view corridors and privacy;
   (13)   To promote and preserve open space, including parks, trails,
landscaped buffer areas, perimeter landscaping, natural washes and other
natural undeveloped areas; and
   (14)   To eliminate or minimize nuisances, clutter and visual blight, and to
prevent pollution or degradation of air, streams, ponds and the night sky.
(Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.01.104: INTERPRETATION:
   (1)   Greater Restrictions Prevail: In their interpretation and application,
the provisions of this title shall be considered as minimum requirements,
unless expressly in conflict with the terms of LUDMA. Where the provisions of
this title impose greater restrictions than LUDMA or any other statute, other
regulations, ordinance or covenant, the provisions of this title shall prevail,
unless expressly in conflict with the terms of LUDMA or any other controlling
statute. Where the provisions of any statute, other regulation, ordinance or
covenant impose greater restrictions than the provision of this title, the
provisions of such statute, other regulation, ordinance or covenant shall
prevail. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
   (2)   Definitions: Whenever any word or phrase used in this title is not
defined herein, but is defined in related sections of Utah Code Annotated or in
this code, such definition is incorporated herein and shall apply as though set
forth herein in full, unless the context clearly indicates a contrary
intention. Unless a contrary intention clearly appears, words used in the
present tense include the future, the singular includes the plural, the term
"shall" is always mandatory and the term "may" is permissive.
   (3)   Severability Of Parts: The various sections, subparagraphs, sentences,
phrases and clauses of this title are hereby declared to be severable. If any
such part of this title is declared to be invalid by a court of competent
jurisdiction or is amended or deleted by the city council, all remaining parts
shall remain valid and in force.
   (4)   Rounding: Rounding to whole numbers may be used to determine distance
or height, but not in determining maximum or minimum area or other quantitative
standards or requirements. A decimal ending with five (5) or greater may be
rounded up to the next whole number.
   (5)   Time Computation: Unless otherwise specified herein, a period of time
specified in this title shall be calendar days beginning on the day after the
act, event or decision to which the time period refers and ending at eleven
fifty nine o'clock (11:59) P.M. the last day of the time period. (Ord. 2006-02,
2006)
15.01.105: COORDINATION WITH OTHER DOCUMENTS:
This title, together with the city general plan ("general plan"), the city
zoning ordinance ("zoning ordinance"), the city design guidelines ("design
guidelines"), and the city standard specifications for design and construction
("standard specifications") shall guide the use of all land within the
municipal boundaries of the city. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.01.106: ORDERLY DEVELOPMENT REQUIRED:
All subdivisions, site plans, condominiums and other developments shall be
developed in an orderly manner and in such a way that the required improvements
will be continuous and available as necessary during construction activities
within the project, and that all of the improvements will be made available for
the full, effective and practical use and enjoyment thereof by the purchaser,
grantee, assignee, transferee or lessee of any of the lands developed within
the time herein provided or in phases specified. Developments shall be planned
and developed to accommodate the continuation of roads, utilities, drainage and
other infrastructure to adjoining properties. Oversizing of lines or
infrastructure in the development may be necessary to accommodate future
development outside of the project. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.01.107: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   (1)   No tract of land shall be divided, subdivided, reconfigured, developed
or redeveloped except in conformance with provisions of this title, the zoning
ordinance and all other applicable ordinances and regulations.
      (a)   All developments that require site plan approvals, even when a
development may not involve the subdivision of lots or require a final plat to
be approved and recorded, shall follow the subdivision application and review
process and all applicable design and construction regulations in this Title 15
Subdivision Regulations.
   (2)   No plat, condominium, subdivision amendment or reconfiguring of
property shall be recorded except in accordance with the provisions of this
title and the zoning ordinance.
   (3)   All licenses, permits, agreements and plans issued or approved by the
city shall comply with all requirements and standards of city ordinances.
   (4)   All subdivisions, condominiums, site plans, construction and
infrastructure shall be designed and constructed in conformance with city
ordinances, engineering regulations and requirements.
   (5)   All uses shall be conducted in conformance with city ordinances,
approved plans and requirements.
   (6)   Land which is to be subdivided shall not be transferred, sold or
offered for sale prior to recording the subject plat or until all requirements
of this title for subdivisions, condominiums or other development have been
met.
   (7)   No building permit may be issued for any structure or development on
any land that has been divided, subdivided, reconfigured, developed or
redeveloped in a manner not in conformance with the provisions of this title,
the zoning ordinance, and all other applicable ordinances and regulations.
(Ord. 2006-02, 2006; Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
15.01.108: AMENDMENTS:
   (1)   The city council may, from time to time and in a manner consistent
with the general plan, amend any provision of this title. Amendments shall be
approved in accordance with all public notice and public hearing requirements
imposed by state law or local ordinance.
   (2)   Any amendment or revision to this title shall supersede any prior
provisions or ordinances. Provisions of this title not affected by the
amendment or revision shall continue to be valid and shall not be considered a
new enactment when amendments or revisions are adopted. Any prior provisions of
city ordinances, which do not conform to provisions of this title, are declared
void. Any uses, structures or buildings which were conforming to previous
provisions of this title but do not now conform shall be nonconforming uses,
structures or buildings. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.01.109: PUBLIC NOTICE:
   (1)   Notice of public hearings and public meetings shall be provided in the
manner set forth in Title 16, Chapter 10 of the Ivins City Code.
   (2)   If notice given under the authority of this section is not challenged
in accordance with applicable appeal procedures thirty (30) days from the date
of the hearing for which the notice was given, the notice is considered
adequate and proper. The notice provided in this section may be referred to in
this title as “required notice”. The cost of required notices shall be paid by
the applicant. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006; amd. Ord. 2016-02, 2016; Ord. 2023-09,
2023)
15.01.110: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION:
In addition to denial, suspension or refusal to act on a developer or
landowner's request, any person who shall violate the provisions of this title
shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor unless otherwise established by law.
Each day of violation shall be considered a separate violation and subject to
the penalties of this section or any other law, ordinance or other provision.
(Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.01.111: APPEALS:
The requirements and procedures for appealing decisions of the city land use
authorities in administering or interpreting the city land use ordinances,
including this title, are set forth in title 16, chapter 30 of this code, and
are hereby incorporated herein by this reference. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
CHAPTER 2
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
15.02.101: General
15.02.102: Definitions
15.02.101: GENERAL:
Unless the context requires otherwise, the following definitions shall be used
in the interpretation and construction of this title. Words used in the present
tense include the future; the singular includes the plural; the word "shall" is
mandatory and not directory; the word "may" is permissive. Words used in this
title, but not defined herein, shall have the meaning first as defined in any
other ordinance adopted by the city and then its common, ordinary meaning.
(Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.02.102: DEFINITIONS:
The definitions set forth in section 10-9a-103 of the Utah Code Annotated,
1953, as amended, and the Ivins City zoning ordinance are hereby incorporated
as additional definitions pertaining to this title.
APPLICANT: The owner of land proposed to be subdivided or such owner's duly
authorized agent. Any agent must have written authorization from the owner.
CITY COUNCIL: The elected city officials consisting of council members and
mayor. Three (3) voting members of the city council constitute a quorum.
CITY ENGINEER: The city engineer of the city or his authorized representative.
CLUSTERED DEVELOPMENT: The development of land with pockets of higher density
land use to encourage the preservation of large pockets of undeveloped land.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/d893e1fd2f01258397edc51c3aecb0cc2a58e863/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2892.gif]
COMMISSION: The Ivins City planning commission.
COMMISSION'S AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE: The planning commission chairperson or
other city employee or official who has been designated by the commission to
represent the city in enforcing or carrying out the functions of the commission
as set forth in this title.
CONCEPT PLAN: A sketch or rough drawing submitted prior to the preliminary plat
for subdivisions to enable a subdivider to reach general agreement with the
planning commission and city staff as to the form of the plat and the
objectives of these regulations and to receive guidance as to the requirements
for subdivisions within Ivins City.
CONVENTIONAL SUBDIVISION: The division of land in a standard and more
traditional configuration of lots.
DESIGN GUIDELINES: The document adopted by the city council to direct and guide
the aesthetics of development in Ivins City.
DEVELOPER: Either: a) an applicant for subdivision approval; b) an applicant
for a building permit or other permit; or c) the owner of any right, title or
interest in real property for which subdivision approvals are sought.
DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT: The agreement between the city and the owner/developer
that outlines the duties, responsibilities, obligations, commitments and
promises of the city and the owner/developer.
DUST CONTROL PLAN: A narrative plan that may include map exhibits prepared by
the developer that establishes management practices to be employed and
temporary facilities to be installed by developer to control fugitive dust that
is released into the air or onto public streets during the construction within
the subdivision.
EASEMENT: Authorization by a property owner for the use by another, and for a
specified purpose, such as utilities and irrigation ditches, of any designated
part of the owner's property. An easement may be for use under, on the surface,
or above the owner's property.
ELECTRONIC FORMAT: Drawings, maps, calculations, documents or other data
required by the city to be provided on a disk readable by an IBM compatible
computer. Types of electronic files including versions will be as requested by
city staff.
ENGINEER: The certified engineer or surveyor, registered with the state to
practice as a professional engineer, engaged by the subdivider to prepare plans
and plats or to compile such data as may be required in connection therewith in
accordance with the provisions of this title or the zoning ordinance.
EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL PLAN: A plan submitted at preliminary plan
and with the construction drawings, including narrative and/or drawings
prepared by the developer, that establishes management practices to be employed
and temporary and permanent facilities to be installed to control soil erosion
and prevent sedimentation impacts to adjacent properties and public facilities
during and after the construction of the subdivision.
FEE SCHEDULE: The schedule or any appendix of fees adopted periodically by
resolution of the city council setting forth various fees charged by the city.
FINAL PLAT: A map of a subdivision, required of all subdivisions, which is
prepared for final approval and recordation, which has been accurately
surveyed, so that streets, lots and other divisions thereof can be identified.
GENERAL PLAN: The Ivins City general plan, as adopted, that sets forth general
guidelines for proposed future development of the land within the city.
GEOTECHNICAL REPORT: A report submitted with the preliminary plan, prepared by
and stamped by a licensed geotechnical engineer that evaluates the existing
soil conditions of the project site prior to new development. The geotechnical
report should include descriptions of generalized site conditions, surface and
subsurface conditions, and recommendations for site preparation, excavation,
grading, structural fill, foundation design, seismic considerations, concrete
design, concrete and metal corrosion protection, pavement design and soil
moisture control. The report would also include exhibits and appendices showing
a vicinity map, site plan, boring locations, boring logs, test results and any
other information used by the geotechnical engineer in determining his or her
design recommendations.
GRADING PLAN: A drawing showing the proposed grading of a subdivision in
reference to the existing topography of the site.
   (1)   Preliminary Grading Plan: A drawing submitted with or incorporated
into the preliminary plan that shows existing contour topography overlaid with
approximate proposed grading information, including contour topography,
retaining wall locations and slopes for the subdivision area.
   (2)   Final Grading Plan: A drawing submitted with the construction drawings
showing the proposed grading of a subdivision site by identifying contour
topography, spot elevations, slopes, curb elevations, road grades, road
profiles, building pad elevations, cross sections, retaining wall elevations,
etc., for existing and proposed conditions.
HYDROLOGY REPORT: A report, prepared by a professional engineer, for the
removal of excess water from the subdivision site. The report shall evaluate
probable storm events that will generate excess water and compares the water
discharges onto and from the site for predevelopment conditions to
postdevelopment conditions. The report shall identify improvements and
management practices to safely convey drainage and mitigate any impacts due to
the proposed subdivision development, all prepared in accordance with the city
standard specifications for design and construction. A preliminary hydrology
report shall be submitted with the preliminary plan. The final hydrology report
shall be submitted with the construction drawings.
LUDMA: The Utah municipal land use development and management act as set forth
as chapter 10-9a of the Utah code.
LANDSCAPED BUFFER AREA (OR STREETSCAPE BUFFER): Landscaped open space along
public streets.
LOT: A parcel of land occupied or proposed to be occupied by a building or
structure, together with such yards, open spaces, lot width and lot area as are
required by the city land use ordinances.
LOT, DOUBLE FRONTAGE (DOUBLE FRONTAGE LOT): A lot where the front lot line and
back lot line both front on a street.
LOT, FLAG (FLAG LOT): A "leftover" lot that has access to a public or private
street by a narrow strip of land.
MODEL HOME: A residential structure that meets all residential occupancy
requirements, used for sales purposes only. A subdivision may have up to a
maximum of five (5) model homes in any subdivision, provided each has a
substantially different floor plan.
OPEN SPACE: Land areas that are not occupied by buildings, structures, parking
areas, streets or roads. Open space may be devoted to landscaping, preservation
of natural features and recreational areas and facilities.
OWNER: Any person who alone, jointly or severally with others, has a legal or
equitable title to property.
PHASED SUBDIVISION: Conventional subdivisions that are proposed to be completed
in designated phases.
PHASED SUBDIVISION MASTER PLAN: A document prepared for future and/or phased
development. The development master plan encompasses the design and general
development parameters for the entire phased development project.
PLANNING COMMISSION: The planning commission of Ivins City, Utah.
PRELIMINARY PLAN: The drawings prepared to indicate the proposed layout of a
subdivision for the purpose of resolving most technical details in compliance
with all regulations.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT: Any street dedications, installations of curb, gutter,
sidewalk, road base and asphalt, water, sewer and storm drainage facilities, or
other utility or service required to provide services to a lot, parcel,
building or structure.
SECURITY AGREEMENT: Agreement to install improvements secured by cash bond,
cash escrow, an irrevocable letter of credit, or any combination of the
preceding as approved by the city council.
STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION (OR STANDARD
SPECIFICATIONS): The standards and construction requirements for improvements,
including streets, water, sewer, storm drainage, etc.
STANDARD SUBDIVISION: A subdivision that conforms to the zoning district in
which it is located without seeking any density bonus or overlay. The approval
or denial of a standard subdivision application is an administrative decision.
STREET:
Cul-De-Sac Street: A minor terminal street provided with a turnaround.
Half Street: The portion of a street within a subdivision comprising at least
one-half (1/2) of the minimum required right of way on which improvements are
constructed and in accordance with one-half (1/2) of an approved typical street
section.
Private Street: A right of way which has been reserved by dedication unto the
subdivider or lot owners, to be used as a private access to serve property and
complying with the adopted street cross section standards of the city for the
type of street as described herein.
Public Street: A public right of way, including a highway, avenue, boulevard,
parkway, road, lane, walk, alley, viaduct, tunnel, bridge, public easement, or
other way. For cross sections and descriptions of various types of public
streets, see the Ivins transportation master plan.
SUBDIVIDER: A person who:
   (1)   Having an interest in land, causes it, directly or indirectly, to be
divided into a subdivision;
   (2)   Directly or indirectly, sells, leases or develops, or offers to sell,
lease or develop, or advertises for sale, lease or development, any interest,
lot, parcel, site, unit or plat in a subdivision;
   (3)   Engages directly, or through an agent, in the business of selling,
leasing, developing or offering for sale, lease or development a subdivision;
or
   (4)   Is directly or indirectly controlled by, or under direct, or indirect
common control with any of the foregoing.
SUBDIVISION: Any land that is divided, resubdivided or proposed to be divided
into two (2) or more lots, parcels, sites, units, plots or other division of
land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, for offer, sale, lease or
development either on the installment plan or upon any and all other plans,
terms and conditions.
   (1)   "Subdivision" includes: a) the division or development of land,
whether by deed, metes and bounds description, devise and testacy, map, plat or
other recorded instrument; and b) except as provided for below, divisions of
land for all residential and nonresidential uses, including land used or to be
used for commercial, agricultural and industrial purposes.
   (2)   "Subdivision" does not include: a) a bona fide division or partition
of agricultural land for the purpose of joining one of the resulting separate
parcels to a contiguous parcel of unsubdivided agricultural land, if neither
the resulting combined parcel nor the parcel remaining from the division or
partition violates an applicable land use ordinance; or b) a recorded agreement
and/or appropriate deed between owners of adjoining unsubdivided properties
adjusting their mutual boundary if no new lot is created and the adjustment
does not violate applicable land use ordinances; or c) a recorded document,
executed by the owner of record, revising the legal description of more than
one contiguous unsubdivided parcel of property into one legal description
encompassing all such parcels of property or joining a subdivided parcel of
property to another parcel of property that has not been subdivided, if the
joinder does not violate applicable land use ordinances. However, if the
location of utility lines or meters is affected, a subdivision application
shall be required.
   (3)   The joining of a subdivided parcel of property to another parcel of
property that has not been subdivided does not constitute a "subdivision" under
this definition as to the unsubdivided parcel or subject the unsubdivided
parcel to this subdivision ordinance.
TECHNICAL REVIEW COMMITTEE: Committee established and created by the city
manager to assure that proposed use, activity, building or structure is
consistent with the general plan and complies with the requirements of the land
use ordinances. Committee members include representatives from city
departments, and other persons as may be designated by the city manager,
responsible for reviewing and coordinating applications for any land use
application approval, permit or license.
TOPOGRAPHIC (TOPO) MAP: A graphic representation of natural and manmade
features of a place or region in such a way as to show their relative positions
and elevations.
UTILITY BOARD: The review board, consisting of city officials and department
heads, which meets monthly with public utilities representatives (i.e., joint
utility committee) to assess utility needs and availability, review subdivision
submittals and conduct other department business.
VICINITY MAP: A map showing project location relative to Ivins City boundaries,
major roads and minor roads that serve the property.
ZONING ADMINISTRATOR: The person designated by the city manager, with the
advice and consent of the mayor and city council, to carry out the
administrative responsibilities of the land use ordinances. It is the
responsibility of the zoning administrator to ensure all procedures and other
provisions of the land use ordinances are consistently and equitably applied.
ZONING ORDINANCE: The Ivins City zoning ordinance, as adopted. (Ord. 2006-02,
2006; amd. Ord. 2007-05, 2007; Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
CHAPTER 3
TYPES OF SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
15.03.101: General
15.03.102: Conventional Subdivision
15.03.103: Phased Subdivision
15.03.101: GENERAL:
All subdivisions of land shall be divided, subdivided, reconfigured, developed
or redeveloped in accordance with the provisions of this title, the state land
sales practices act, the zoning ordinance, the general plan, the design
guidelines, the standard specifications, and all other applicable ordinances in
this code and the state code. Specific procedures for each type of subdivision
are outlined in chapters of this title as noted below. General subdivision
procedures are outlined in chapter 4 of this title. General design regulations
are outlined in chapter 5 of this title. Procedures for phased subdivisions
have additional requirements as outlined below. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.03.102: CONVENTIONAL SUBDIVISION 1 :
The purpose and intent of the conventional subdivision procedure is to allow
the division of land in all zones in a standard and more traditional
configuration of lots. While creative and innovative land development is
encouraged, the conventional subdivision may be best suited for smaller acreage
subdivisions and/or tract developments. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 4 of this title for approval process and chapter 5 of this
  title for required improvements.
15.03.103: PHASED SUBDIVISION 1 :
Conventional subdivisions may be phased subdivisions if the project is proposed
to be completed in designated phases. The purpose of the phased subdivision
procedure is to provide general development parameters for subdivision phases
in the phased subdivision master plan prior to the detailed and comprehensive
requirements of the preliminary plan and final plat. The owner/developer shall
enter into a development agreement with the city that outlines the duties,
responsibilities, obligations, commitments and promises of the parties. (Ord.
2006-02, 2006)
 
Notes
  2. See chapter 4 of this title for approval process, chapter 5 of this title
1 for required improvements, and chapter 6 of this title for additional
  standards and requirements.
CHAPTER 4
SUBDIVISION APPLICATION AND REVIEW PROCESS
SECTION:
Part 1. Pre-Application Consultation
15.04.101: Purpose Of Consultation
15.04.102: Applicability
15.04.103: Time
15.04.104: Feedback
15.04.105: No Vesting
Part 2. Preliminary Plan
15.04.201: Purpose
15.04.202: Application
15.04.203: Review Process
15.04.204: Approval And Expiration
Part 3. Final Plat
15.04.301: Purpose
15.04.302: Application
15.04.303: Review Process
15.04.304: Approval And Expiration
15.04.305: Development Agreement
15.04.306: Preparation Of Final Plat Mylar; City Signatures On Mylar
15.04.307: Final Plat Recording
PART 1. PRE-APPLICATION CONSULTATION
15.04.101: PURPOSE OF CONSULTATION:
The purpose of the pre-application consultation is to provide an opportunity
for an informal evaluation of the applicant's proposed subdivision and to
familiarize the applicant with the applicable provisions of the General Plan,
Zoning Ordinance, this Title, infrastructure requirements and any other issues
that may affect the applicant's proposal in planning and designing the
subdivision. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
15.04.102: APPLICABILITY:
A pre-application consultation may be requested by an applicant prior to
submittal of a preliminary plan application. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord.
2024-07, 2024)
15.04.103: TIME:
If such a request is made by an applicant, the city shall, within 15 business
days after the request, schedule a meeting with the technical review committee
to review applicant's pre-application and give initial feedback. An electronic
copy of the pre-application plan is to be provided with the application. (Ord.
2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
15.04.104: FEEDBACK:
At the pre-application meeting, city staff shall provide or have available on
the city website, the following:
   (1)   Copies of applicable land use regulations;
   (2)   A complete list of standards required for the project;
   (3)   Preliminary and final application checklists; and
   (4)   Feedback on the pre-application plan. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord.
2024-07, 2024)
15.04.105: NO VESTING:
The pre-application consultation is an informal evaluation and does not vest
the applicant with any property development rights. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd.
Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
PART 2. PRELIMINARY PLAN
15.04.201: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the preliminary plan is to review and resolve most of the
technical details of the subdivision design in order to minimize changes and
revisions, which might otherwise be necessary on the final plat. The
preliminary plan, and all information and procedures relating thereto, shall in
all respects be in compliance with the provisions of this title and all other
applicable ordinances, including the General Plan which should be utilized in
planning and designing the subdivision. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07,
2024)
15.04.202: APPLICATION:
A preliminary plan application shall be completed by the applicant using the
form provided by the City and shall be submitted to the City zoning
administrator. It shall include the following:
   (1)   Owner's signed affidavit and consent.
   (2)   The full payment of the preliminary plan application fee set by city
council resolution.
   (3)   Subdivision preliminary plan. One (1) twenty-four inch by thirty-six
inch (24" x 36") or larger copies of the subdivision preliminary plan, one (1)
eleven inch by seventeen inch (11" x 17") reduced copies of the subdivision
preliminary plan, and one (1) copy of the proposed subdivision preliminary plan
in electronic format. The preliminary plan must include the following elements:
   
      (a)   Names, addresses and phone numbers of applicant, as well as
applicant's engineer, surveyor and/or architect.
      (b)   Vicinity map showing the project locations relative to city
boundaries, major roads and minor roads that serve the property;
      (c)   Date, scale, north arrow, name of subdivision (applicant must check
with the Washington County recorder to determine if proposed subdivision name
has been used);
      (d)   The assessor's parcel number, address, acreage, dimensions and
certified legal description (prepared by licensed surveyor) of the property to
be subdivided;
      (e)   Existing streets (with names) and right of way widths, buildings,
culverts, bridges, waterways, irrigation ditches and systems, wells, springs,
utilities, fencing, easements, rights of way, flood boundary, surface
watercourse features, geologic hazards, parks, trails, open space, storm drain
and sanitary sewer systems, topography (contours at maximum two foot (2')
intervals), survey monuments, section lines, other features and infrastructure
on or adjacent to the property or other information requested by the public
works director or city engineer;
      (f)   Proposed subdivision boundary and dimensions, streets (with names
and widths), lot layout, lot sizes and dimensions, phasing, gross lot density,
curbs, gutters, park strips and landscaping, water ways, demolition, sidewalks,
fencing, easements, parks, trails, open space, public land dedications, storm
and subsurface drainage systems, detention areas and potential flood boundary,
sanitary and any other infrastructure or improvements on or adjacent to the
subject property and other information requested by the public works director
or city engineer;
      (g)   All property lines of adjacent properties within one hundred fifty
feet (150') of the boundary of the proposed subdivision with the names of the
owners and the parcel tax identification numbers;
      (h)   "Preliminary grading plan" as defined in chapter 2 of this title,
and in accordance with the standard specifications;
      (i)   Preliminary landscaping plan; and
      (j)   Preliminary lighting plan.
   (4)   Traffic impact study, as required by the transportation master plan,
in electronic format.
   (5)   "Geotechnical report", as defined in chapter 2 of this title and in
accordance with the standard specifications, in electronic format.
   (6)   Preliminary "hydrology report", as defined in chapter 2 of this title
and in accordance with the standard specifications, in electronic format.
   (7)   Preliminary title report verifying ownership of the property being
subdivided (subject property").
   (8)   Documentation regarding agreements with adjacent owners, agreements
for the provision of utilities and easements, encumbrances and traffic impacts,
as well as any documentation regarding compliance with any federal, state, or
local requirements affecting the subject property.
   (9)   If the application is for a subdivision that does not meet the
definition of a "standard subdivision", the applicant shall provide a list of
names and addresses, and two (2) sets of address labels and postage, for owners
of record of properties located within three hundred feet (300') of the
boundary line of the subject property.
      (a)   The list must be no older than thirty (30) days from the date of
submission.
      (b)   The applicant is responsible for the completeness and accuracy of
the list but is entitled to rely upon the records in the Washington County
recorder's office.
      (c)   Failure to provide an accurate list may delay the approval of the
subdivision.
   (10)   For phased subdivisions, include a phasing master plan indicating the
areas to be phased and the proposed sequence of each phase.
   (11)   A plan for the continued maintenance of the subdivision amenities,
such as the use of a homeowners' association. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord.
2024-07, 2024)
15.04.203: REVIEW PROCESS:
   (1)   Standards For Review:
      (a)   The proposed subdivision shall conform to the zoning ordinance,
design guidelines, standard specifications, and all relevant sections of this
title.
      (b)   The capacity and adequacy of public services and utility services
must be adequate to service the proposed subdivision. Services required for the
proposed subdivision may include roads, gas, electric, telephone, mail, police
and fire protection, water, sewer and recreation.
      (c)   Preliminary engineering plans shall indicate that public services
(including roads, fire, police, gas, water, sewer, electricity, telephone and
recreation) are available and meet the requirements of this title and all
applicable codes and regulations. If public improvements are not available, the
technical review committee may recommend one of the following to assure that
adequate public services are available at the time of final plat recording:
         (i)   Allow the applicant to voluntarily construct those public
improvements which are necessary to service development as determined by the
technical review committee by entering into an appropriate form of development
agreement;
         (ii)   Allow the applicant to phase the proposed development
consistent with the availability of adequate public improvements;   
         (iii)   Defer final plat approval and issuance of building permits
until all necessary public improvements are adequate and available; or
         (iv)   Deny the preliminary plan approval and allow the applicant to
reapply when adequate public improvements are available.
   (2)   Completeness Review:
      (a)   The zoning administrator and the technical review committee shall
review the preliminary plan application for completeness.
      (b)   If an application is determined to be incomplete, the zoning
administrator shall provide notice to the applicant along with an explanation
of the application's deficiencies. There will be no further review or
consideration of an incomplete application until the applicant submits
additional information to cure the deficiencies.
      (c)   An application will only be considered complete if it:
         (i)   Includes all required forms, plans, reports, documents and other
support materials; and   
         (ii)   Includes payment of the full application fee as set forth on
the City's fee schedule.
      (d)   Additional supplementary materials may be submitted after a
completeness review is complete and the application has been accepted for
review, provided they are submitted at least thirty (30) days prior to the
first public meeting or hearing to be held on the application. The City may
postpone and reschedule a public meeting or hearing if such materials are
submitted less than thirty (30) days prior to the public meeting or hearing.
   (3)   Substantive Review:
      (a)   Technical Review Committee: After the preliminary plan application
is determined to be complete, it shall be scheduled for a substantive review by
the technical review committee. The technical review committee shall provide
the applicant with written comments and necessary corrections. The applicant
shall then respond to the written comments, make the necessary corrections and
submit a revised plan (if required) before the application can proceed. Upon
receiving applicant's response, corrections and revised plan (if required), the
revised plan may be scheduled for a second review by the technical review
committee. If the technical review committee determines that the applicant has
properly responded to the prior written comments, made the necessary
corrections, submitted a revised plan (if required) and meets the requirements
for preliminary plan submittals, the zoning administrator shall prepare a staff
report and schedule the preliminary plan application for review and
consideration by the planning commission. If the application did not fully
respond to the written comments, make all the necessary corrections and submit
a revised plan as required, the application cannot proceed. Before the
application is scheduled for further review by the technical review committee,
the applicant must pay in advance the required fee or such additional review
(s).
      (b)   Planning Commission: For standard subdivisions, once the technical
review committee has completed its review and determined that the preliminary
plan application is ready to be reviewed and considered by the planning
commission, the preliminary plan application will be scheduled on the planning
commission agenda for review and approval. Any subdivision that does not meet
the definition of a "standard subdivision" shall require a public hearing prior
to approval by the planning commission. Notice of public meetings and public
hearing, if required, shall be given as set forth in Title 16, Chapter 10 of
the Ivins City Code.
   (4)   Special Technical Review:
      (a)   The technical review committee will determine if the project has
complex technical issues that require in-depth special technical reviews by
third party contractors hired by the City. A list of possible complex technical
issues could include presence of expansive clay soils, high traffic generation,
high water usage, or other geologic hazards. If more than two (2) reviews are
necessary, applicant will be required to pay an extra fee based on the
additional costs of these services.
      (b)   If third party contractors are hired by the City to review these
types of issues, the applicant will be required to pay an extra fee based on
the additional costs of these services. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07,
2024)
15.04.204: APPROVAL AND EXPIRATION:
A preliminary plan approval shall remain valid for one year from the date of
approval. If a final plat is not approved within one year of the date of the
preliminary plan approval, the preliminary plan shall expire and become null
and void. The planning commission may grant a one-time six (6) month extension
for obtaining final plat approval, provided the applicant submits the request
for extension prior to expiration of the preliminary plan, uses the required
city form and pays the required fees in full. In the event a preliminary plan
expires, the applicant will have to completely restart the approval process.
For multi-phased subdivisions, final plat for at least one phase must be
approved within one (1) year of the preliminary plan approval. The preliminary
plan for all phases for which a final plat has not been approved will expire
three (3) years from the date of the preliminary plan approval unless otherwise
specified in a written development agreement approved by the city council.
(Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
PART 3. FINAL PLAT
15.04.301: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the final plat is to verify that it conforms to the approved
preliminary plan prior to recording with the Washington County recorder. A
final plat application shall be submitted to the city only after the
preliminary plan has been approved. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07,
2024)
15.04.302: APPLICATION:
The final plat application shall be completed by the applicant using the form
provided by the city and shall be submitted to the city zoning administrator.
It shall include the following:
   (1)   Applicant's signed affidavit and consent.
   (2)   The full payment of the final plat application fee set by city council
resolution.
   (3)   A current title report, dated not more than thirty (30) days before
the proposed recording of the final plat, showing the identity of the vested
owner(s) and all recorded matters of title regarding the property being
subdivided. Applicant must provide additional documentation of owning entities
that are not individuals that is satisfactory to the technical review
committee.
   (4)   When a subdivision contains lands which are reserved in private
ownership for community use, including common areas, the applicant shall submit
with the final plat, the name, articles of incorporation and bylaws of the
owner, or organization empowered to own, maintain and pay taxes on such lands
and common areas with proof of filing with the state.
   (5)   The plan for continued maintenance of common areas and public areas.
   (6)   Subdivision final plat. One (1) twenty-four inch by thirty-six inch
(24" x 36") or larger copies of the subdivision final plat, one (1) eleven inch
by seventeen inch (11" x 17") reduced copies of the subdivision final plat, and
one (1) copy of the subdivision final plat in electronic format. The final plat
application must include the following elements:   
      (a)   Names, addresses and phone numbers of applicant, as well as
applicant's engineer, surveyor and/or architect;
      (b)   The subdivision name prominently printed on the plat;
      (c)   Vicinity map showing the project locations relative to city
boundaries, major roads and minor roads that serve the property;
      (d)   Date, scale and north arrow;
      (e)   The assessor's parcel number, address, acreage, dimensions and
certified legal description prepared by a Utah licensed surveyor of the
property to be subdivided;
      (f)   An accurately drawn subdivision boundary showing proper bearings
and dimensions properly tied to public survey monuments and drawn slightly
bolder than lot and street lines;
      (g)   All survey and mathematical information and data necessary to
locate all monuments, to locate and retrace all interior and exterior boundary
lines appearing thereon, including bearing and distance of straight lines, and
central angle, radius and arc length of curves, and such information as may be
necessary to determine the location of beginning and ending points of curves.
All boundary corners and monuments within the subdivision shall show the Utah
coordinate system 1983 south zone grid coordinates and shall reference existing
monumentation on the Washington County horizontal control network. Lot and
boundary closure shall be calculated to the nearest one-hundredth (1/100) of a
foot.
      (h)   All lots, blocks and parcels offered for dedication for any purpose
delineated and designated with dimensions, boundaries and courses clearly shown
and defined in every case. The square footage of each lot shall be shown.
Parcels offered for dedication, other than for streets or easements, shall be
clearly designated on the plat. Sufficient linear, angular and curved data
shall be shown to determine readily the bearing and length of the boundary
lines of every block, lot and parcel which is part thereof. No ditto marks
shall be used for lot dimensions.
      (i)   The right of way lines of each street and the width of any portion
being dedicated and widths of any existing dedications. The widths and
locations of adjacent streets and other public properties within one hundred
fifty feet (150') of the subdivision shall be shown with dashed lines. If any
street in the subdivision is a continuation or an approximate continuation of
an existing street, the conformity or the amount of nonconformity of such
existing streets shall be accurately shown.
      (j)   All lots and blocks numbered consecutively under a definite system
approved by the city engineer. Numbering shall continue consecutively
throughout the subdivision with no omissions or duplications.
      (k)   All streets within the subdivision shall be numbered (named streets
shall also be numbered) in accordance with, and in conformity with, the adopted
street system of the city. Named streets are optional; however, all named
streets must also be numbered. In the case of corner lots, an address may be
assigned for each part of the lot having street frontage.
      (l)   The sidelines of all easements shall be shown by fine dashed lines.
The width of all easements, and sufficient ties thereto to definitely locate
the same with respect to the subdivision, shall be shown. All easements shall
be clearly labeled and identified. Easements shall be ten feet (10') from the
property line for all front yards and seven and one-half feet (7½') from the
property line for all side and rear yards. Larger easements may be required
under specific circumstances requiring greater areas.
      (m)   All fully and clearly shown stakes, monuments and other evidence
indicating the boundaries of the subdivision as found on the site. Any monument
or benchmark that is disturbed or destroyed before acceptance of all
improvements shall be replaced by the developer under the direction of the city
engineer. The following required monuments shall be shown on the final plat:
         (i)   The location of all monuments placed in making the survey,
including a statement as what, if any, points were reset by ties; and
         (ii)   All right of way monuments at angle points and intersections as
approved by the city engineer.
      (n)   The name of the surveyor, together with the date of the survey, the
scale of the map and the number of sheets. The following certificates,
acknowledgments and descriptions shall appear on the title sheet of the final
plat, and such certificates may be combined where appropriate:
         (i)   Registered land surveyor's "certificate of survey" in a form
acceptable to the city;
         (ii)   Owner's "dedication certificate" in a form acceptable to the
city;
         (iii)   Necessary notary public's acknowledgment of signatures; and
         (iv)   A correct metes and bounds description of all property included
within the subdivision.
      (o)   Plats shall contain blocks for signature of the city engineer, city
attorney, planning commission and city council. (A signature line for the mayor
and an attestation by the city recorder.) A block for the Washington County
recorder shall be provided in the lower right corner of the final plat.
      (p)   Such other affidavits, certificates, acknowledgments, endorsements
and notarial seals as are required by law, by this title, city staff, city
engineer or city attorney.
      (q)   Other information such as the location of jurisdictional boundary
lines (federal emergency management agency, U.S. army corps or corps of
engineers, bureau of land management, U.S. fish and wildlife service, state
institutional trust lands agency, etc.), adjoining lot lines or property
owners, fencing notes, or any other special notes or requirements as deemed
appropriate by the city staff, city engineer, city attorney or city council.
      (r)   The developer shall note on the final plat those public right of
way areas, including public park strips.
      (s)   All easements and rights of way within or required for the
subdivision shall be shown on the plat.
   (7)   Stamped engineered construction drawings. Submit three (3) copies in
accordance with the standards provided in Chapter 5 of this title and the
standard specifications. Review and approval of these drawings will be in
accordance with the standard specifications.
   (8)   Cost estimate of all required improvements in accordance with the
standard specifications.
   (9)   Final drainage report. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
15.04.303: REVIEW PROCESS:
   (1)   Completeness Review:
      (a)   The zoning administrator and the technical review committee shall
review the final plat application for completeness.
      (b)   If an application is determined to be incomplete, the zoning
administrator shall provide notice to the applicant along with an explanation
of the application's deficiencies. There will be no further review or
consideration of an incomplete application until the applicant submits
additional information to cure the deficiencies.
      (c)   An application will only be considered complete if it:
         (i)   Includes all required forms, plans, reports, documents and other
support materials; and   
         (ii)   Includes payment of the full application fee as set forth on
the city's fee schedule.
      (d)   Additional supplementary materials may be submitted after a
completeness review is complete and the application has been accepted for
review, provided they are submitted at least thirty (30) days prior to the
first public meeting or hearing to be held on the application. The city may
postpone and reschedule a public meeting or hearing if such materials are
submitted less than thirty (30) days prior to the public meeting or hearing.
   (3)   Substantive Review:
      (a)   Technical Review Committee: After the final plat application is
determined to be complete, it shall be scheduled for a substantive review by
the technical review committee. The technical review committee shall provide
the applicant with written comments and necessary corrections. The applicant
shall then respond to the written comments, make the necessary corrections and
submit a revised plan, if required, before the application can proceed. Upon
receiving applicant's response, corrections and revised plan (if required), the
final plat application may be scheduled for a second review by the technical
review committee. If the technical review determines that the applicant has
properly responded to the prior written comments, made the necessary
corrections and submitted a revised plan (if required) meets the requirements
for final plat submittals, the zoning administrator shall prepare a staff
report and schedule the final plat application for review and consideration by
the Final Plat Review Authority. If the applicant did not fully respond to the
written comments, make all the necessary corrections and submit a revised plan
as required, the application cannot proceed. Before the application is
scheduled for further review by the technical review committee, the applicant
must pay in advance the required fee or such additional review(s).
      (b)   Final Plat Review Authority: The Final Plat Review Authority shall
be made up of the City Engineer or Assistant Engineer. Once the technical
review committee has completed its review and determined that the final plat
application is ready to be reviewed and considered by the Final Plat Review
Authority, the final plat application will be submitted to the Final Plat
Review Authority for approval. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
15.04.304: APPROVAL AND EXPIRATION:
A final plat approval shall remain valid for one year from the date of
approval. If a final plat is not recorded within one (1) year of the date of
the final plat approval, the final plat shall expire. The Final Plat Review
Authority may grant a one-time six (6) month extension for recording the final
plat, provided the applicant submits the request for extension prior to
expiration of the final plat, uses the required city form and pays the required
fees in full. In the event a final plat expires, the applicant will have six
(6) months to reapply for final plat approval. If the applicant fails to
reapply for final plat approval within six (6) months of expiration, then all
previous approvals shall be null and void, requiring the applicant to
completely restart the approval process. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-
07, 2024)
15.04.305: DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT:
   (1)   A development agreement is not required as a condition for developing
land if the city's land use regulations establish all applicable standards for
development on the land.
   (2)   A development agreement will be required for all phased subdivisions
to memorialize such things as the timing of the phasing, the minimum number of
lots to be included in a phase, and an infrastructure plan that will ensure
each phase has all required infrastructure installed prior to the first
certificate of occupancy being issued. At a minimum, the final plat for the
first subdivision phase must be recorded within one (1) year from the approval
date of the development agreement and the required paved fire access roads for
each phase is either fully installed or bonded prior to issuing the first
certificate of occupancy for each phase. (Ord. 2023-22, 2023; amd. Ord. 2024-
07, 2024)
15.04.306:   PREPARATION OF FINAL PLAT MYLAR; CITY SIGNATURES ON MYLAR:
   (1)   Preparation Of Final Plat Mylar: Once all requirements have been met,
redline corrections made, revised plans and plat submitted, city staff review
completed, and the Final Plat Review Authority has approved the final plat, the
applicant shall submit a twenty four inch by thirty six inch (24" x 36") Mylar
drawing of the corrected final plat with the signatures of the owners,
lienholders and other required signatures.
   (2)   City Signatures On Final Plat Mylar:
      (a)   Final Plat Review Authority: Upon approval of the final plat, the
Final Plat Review Authority and the mayor shall sign the Mylar.
      (b)   City Engineer: The city engineer shall review the Mylar and verify
that the information thereon complies with the approved final plat and that it
remains in compliance with general good engineering practices, engineering and
surveying standards set forth in this title, other applicable Ivins City
ordinances, and engineering and surveying standards adopted by the Ivins City
council. The city engineer shall also confirm that the survey description is
correct and that all easements are correctly described and located on the
Mylar. Once the city engineer has reviewed the foregoing and is satisfied that
the Mylar is in compliance with all requirements of this title, he shall sign
the Mylar.
      (c)   City Attorney Review: The city attorney shall review the Mylar and
the current title report. The legal description in the title report shall be
compared, for accuracy, with any legal description on the Mylar, in the
restrictive covenants, articles, consents and other legal documents. All
persons shown on the title report as owners or lienholders must have signed the
Mylar and had their signature acknowledged by a notary on the plat. All
lienholder consents must not only show consent to recording of the plat and any
restrictive covenants, but must also indicate the lienholder's approval of, and
joinder in the dedication of, any public streets or rights of way and all
lienholders must have signed the Mylar indicating such. The city attorney shall
also verify that the applicant has submitted the required improvement
guarantee, verification from the Washington County treasurer that all taxes or
special assessments payable on all property within the subdivision, including
any interest and penalties thereon, have been paid in full, verification from
the Washington County water conservancy district that all water impact fees
have been satisfied, and any other documents and information required by the
city attorney. Once the city attorney has reviewed the foregoing and is
satisfied that the Mylar is in compliance with all requirements of this title,
he shall sign the Mylar. (Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
15.04.307:   FINAL PLAT RECORDING:
The city recorder, or designee, shall record the final plat at the office of
the Washington County recorder. The final plat may not be recorded until all of
the following items have been completed:
   (1)   The final plat has been approved by the Final Plat Review Authority
and all requirements of the city engineer and city attorney have been met;
   (2)   All required signatures, including the mayor's signature and the city
recorder's certification have been applied to the Mylar plat drawing;
   (3)   The security for improvements as determined by the city engineer and
approved by the city attorney has been properly posted with the city recorder
or improvements have been completed and accepted by the city;
   (4)   All necessary deeds and agreements have been executed and submitted to
the city;
   (5)   A development agreement, if applicable, for the project has been
signed and approved;
   (6)   All impact fees, development fees and other fees have been paid to the
city;
   (7)   Verification from the Washington County treasurer that all taxes or
special assessments payable on all property within the subdivision, including
any interest and penalties thereon, have been paid in full; and
   (8)   Where required, verification from the Washington County water
conservancy district that all water impact fees have been paid. (Ord. 2024-07,
2024)
