PART 1. REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS AND GENERAL PROVISIONS
15.05.101: REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS:
The following improvements, utilities and services shall be provided by a
developer of a subdivision, condominiums, or any development that requires that
public services be provided to serve the development in accordance with the
general requirements listed above:
   (1)   A public street system including curb, gutters, sidewalks, street
paving, landscaped buffers and other necessary appurtenances in accordance with
the transportation master plan and other city ordinances. Private streets may
be alternatively provided where appropriate in accordance with the
transportation master plan. Access to the development shall be in accordance
with city adopted fire code.
   (2)   A culinary water system, including the mains, valves, blowoffs, fire
hydrants, pressure reducing valves and service laterals to each lot or parcel
in the project.
   (3)   A public sanitary sewer system, including the mains, manholes, and
service laterals which must be extended from the sewer main to each lot or
parcel in the project.
      (a)   When allowed by section
10.03.302 of this code, a developer may require each individual subdivided lot
to provide an advanced on site wastewater treatment system in lieu of providing
a public sanitary sewer system.
   (4)   A secondary water system to provide water for outside landscaping to
each lot in the project. The secondary water system shall be of similar type
and requirements as the culinary water system and shall comply with all related
standards and specifications.
   (5)   A subsurface water drain system shall be provided when deemed
necessary by site conditions to lower or remove shallow groundwater on the
site. The system shall be inspected and approved by the city and shall become
the responsibility of the homeowners and/or developer. The city shall not be
responsible for the maintenance or failure of the subsurface drains or for
damage resulting from inadequate, clogged, or defective drains.
   (6)   A storm drainage system and detention basins shall be installed as
required by the city. The drainage shall comply with drainage studies,
downstream facilities and capacities, and shall conform to the general plan and
the city's storm drain capital facilities plan. All developments are required
to provide safe and adequate drainage for the existing flows occurring on, or
passing through, the project.
   (7)   Provisions for other franchised utilities such as power, phone, gas,
and cable TV as necessary for the project. The developer is required to
coordinate the installation and maintenance of these utilities.
   (8)   Permanent monuments shall be furnished, accurately established and set
by a certified Utah licensed land surveyor at such points as necessary to
define and establish all lot lines and rights of way within the project.
   (9)   Street signs shall be installed in conformance with city standards.
   (10)   Streetlights in conformance with city standards shall be installed at
all street intersections, school and pedestrian crossings, and on public
streets at intervals and locations specified by the standard specifications.
   (11)   Fencing shall be provided where required in accordance with this
chapter and all other city ordinances.
   (12)   Extensions of off site utilities and other facilities that are
necessary to provide services to the proposed project in accordance with
standards as required by the city. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.102: DESIGN STANDARDS:
All improvements in the proposed project shall be in accordance with city
standards specifications, city design guidelines, and development standards of
title 16, "Zoning Regulations", of this code. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.103: ARCHITECTURAL STYLE:
The exterior color and materials of all buildings, structures, walls and fences
shall comply with the design guidelines. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.104: PRESERVATION OF NATURAL FEATURES:
Existing major natural geographic and landmark topographic land features,
including major rock formations, major washes, wetlands and lava rock, shall be
preserved and may not be removed or damaged, except in conformance with
approved development plans and in conformance with this title and the zoning
ordinance. Development shall be designed to minimize excavation and scarring of
these natural features. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.105: PREPARATION OF CONSTRUCTION PLANS:
Complete and detailed construction plans and drawings of all improvements shall
be prepared in conformance to the standard specifications. Refer to the
standard specifications for required elements and submittal requirements. They
shall be submitted to the city for review at the same time the final plat is
being reviewed. Final approval of the project shall not be granted until the
plans have been reviewed and recommended for approval by the city engineer.
Plans for all street utilities shall be included in the same plans. (Ord. 2016-
02, 2016)
15.05.106:   SEPARATE APPLICATION FOR REVIEW OF CONSTRUCTION PLANS:
Construction plans are submitted with the final plat application for all
subdivisions. For developments that are not subdivisions and do not require a
recorded plat but do have an approved site plan that would require site
construction plans to be approved by the public works department and the City
Engineer, a separate application shall be made to the public works/engineering
department for review and approval. The following items shall be submitted:
   (1)   Application form.
   (2)   Application fee set by resolution by the city council.
   (3)   Stamped engineered construction drawings. Submit three (3) copies in
accordance with this chapter, to be reviewed and approved in accordance with
the standard specifications.
   (4)   Final Drainage Study (if not approved prior).
   (5)   Maintenance and inspection agreement for low impact development
facilities.
   (6)   Cost estimate of all required improvements in accordance with the
standard specifications. (Ord. 2024-07, 2024)
PART 2. LOTS AND PARCELS
15.05.201: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
The following requirements pertaining to subdivisions or other developments
shall be incorporated into project design and implemented by the developer:
   (1)   Each lot or parcel shall be of adequate shape and size to accommodate
yard area, frontage/width, parking, access, landscaping, building and other
requirements of the zoning district in which the lot or parcel is proposed and
to accommodate reasonable use of the property.
   (2)   Allowances for existing topography, easements, vegetation, waterways
and other natural or historic features of the property shall be accommodated in
the design of lots or parcels.
   (3)   Individual lots or parcels may not be created which would be divided
by a city boundary or a zone boundary. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.202: GRADING REQUIREMENTS:
Grading shall conform with standard specifications, title 16, "Zoning
Regulations", of this code, and all adopted codes and regulations. (Ord. 2016-
02, 2016)
15.05.203: DOUBLE FRONTAGE LOTS:
Double frontage lots may only be allowed where lots back onto collector or
arterial streets.
   (1)   On a case by case basis, double frontage lots may be approved
elsewhere due to:
      (a)   Property constraints;
      (b)   Traffic considerations; or
      (c)   Other special circumstances.
   (2)   Where double frontage lots are approved, the following may be
required:
      (a)   An approved decorative masonry wall along the rear lot;
      (b)   Limited access on arterial and collector streets;
      (c)   No access from the street which is established along the rear of
the lot; and
      (d)   Altered park strips and sidewalks along the rear frontages of the
lot.
   (3)   The minimum lot width for corner lots shall be ten feet (10') wider
than the minimum width required for an interior lot in the same zone. (Ord.
2016-02, 2016)
15.05.204: FLAG LOTS:
   (1)   Flag lots may only be allowed under the following conditions:
      (a)   Significant natural features exist on the property that are not
created by the applicant, such that a flag lot would better utilize the
irregularly shaped properties;
      (b)   The flag lot facilitates infill development; or
      (c)   The flag lot eliminates access to an arterial street.
   (2)   Where flag lots are allowed, the following shall be required:
      (a)   The access strip to a flag lot shall be a minimum of twenty feet
(20'), shall be part of the lot and no access shall be permitted across another
property;
      (b)   The large portion of the flag lot shall meet all lot width and yard
requirements for the zoning district in which it is located. The narrow portion
of the lot, however, may be included in the calculation of the lot area;
      (c)   The "leftover" lot resulting from the creation of a flag lot shall
also meet all the width and yard requirements for the zoning district in which
it is located; and
      (d)   All flag lots shall have frontage upon a dedicated roadway or a
publicly approved street. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 3. STREETS AND ROADS
15.05.301: TRANSPORTATION MASTER PLAN CONFORMANCE:
The subdivision plan shall be in compliance with the city transportation master
plan. Applicants shall take into account proposed streets and street widths
indicated in the transportation master plan. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.302: STREET REQUIREMENTS:
Streets shall be designed and constructed according to the cross sections,
policies, and design standards set forth in Ivins transportation master plan
and city standard specifications.
   (1)   The developer shall dedicate right of way and install improvements for
proposed streets which are planned to adjoin or traverse the project or which
are necessary for the development. The entire proposed right of way shall be
dedicated to the city according to the design width specified by the Ivins
transportation master plan. The city may participate in a percentage of the
cost of improvements for arterial and major collector streets as proposed in
the Ivins City capital facilities plan.
   (2)   Subdivisions and other developments shall be designed to provide
future access to adjoining vacant parcels. Developments shall also be designed
so that existing stub streets in existing developments will be connected to the
proposed streets and accesses. Where a stub street is provided which accesses
more than two (2) lots on each side, a temporary turnaround and public use
easement at least eighty feet (80') in diameter, or equivalent hammerhead
turnaround, shall be provided as approved by the fire marshal. The city may
require improvements to be installed in temporary turnaround areas.
   (3)   Generally, fire apparatus access roads, including cul-de-sac and dead
end streets, may not exceed seven hundred fifty feet (750') in length, as
measured from the center of the intersection of a connecting through street to
the center of the turnaround area, without special approval by the city council
for circumstances where it would be impracticable to comply with the seven
hundred fifty foot (750') maximum length. The maximum length of a cul-de-sac
street may not be extended by additional turnarounds between the intersecting
through street and the cul- de-sac. However, if the distance from the end of a
proposed cul- de-sac to a connecting road is less than two hundred feet (200'),
where conditions permit, connection to the connecting road shall be required if
doing so does not violate requirements of the Ivins City transportation master
plan, does not disturb or eliminate any unique geographical feature, including
boundaries where the abutting property is tortoise habitat, state park, Indian
reservation or owned by the bureau of land management (BLM) thereby making it
impracticable to install a connecting road, and does not prevent full
development of approved densities.
   (4)   Cul-de-sacs shall have a minimum pavement turnaround diameter of
ninety six feet (96') with a minimum right of way line diameter of one hundred
fifteen feet (115').
   (5)   Streets in subdivisions, excluding collector streets, exceeding eighty
feet (80') in length are encouraged to be curvilinear or provide sufficient
alignment variation to calm traffic and enhance aesthetic appeal in the
subdivision.
   (6)   Subdivision streets shall be designed to approach an arterial or
collector street in accordance with the standard specifications. (Ord. 2016-02,
2016)
15.05.303: SIDEWALK REQUIREMENTS:
Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of public and private streets, with
exceptions for low volume roads as identified in the transportation master
plan.
   (1)   A ten foot (10') asphalt trail may substitute for sidewalks on both
sides of the street in the identified rural zone. Landscaped areas, in
compliance with the design guidelines, between the street curb and gutter and
the sidewalk, and between the sidewalk and outside right of way boundary, are
encouraged.
   (2)   The sidewalk may be placed in the landscaped buffer area.
   (3)   If sidewalks serving public streets are not placed within a dedicated
right of way, an easement for access and maintenance will be required.
   (4)   The minimum sidewalk width requirements shall be in accordance with
the cross sections depicted in the transportation master plan and the standard
specifications.
   (5)   Required sidewalk and bike paths shall be serpentined on streets with
a landscape buffer greater than fifteen feet (15') wide. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 4. LANDSCAPED BUFFER AREAS
15.05.401: PURPOSE:
Landscaped buffer areas are intended to provide an area of landscaped open
space along all public streets which form the perimeter of the subdivision
where front yards of homes do not front the street and on all public streets
within the subdivision where front yards of homes do not front the street. The
intent is to provide the general public using the public streets with a more
open view of the scenic vistas prominent in the community and a less congested
experience as they travel along the public streets within the community. It is
further the intent to provide a common and consistent appearance of all public
streets within the community. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.402: DEDICATION AND MAINTENANCE:
After satisfactory installation of the landscaping in the landscaped buffer
area, and one hundred percent (100%) release of the security for said
landscaping, the city will accept the dedication of, and responsibility for
maintenance of, the landscaped buffer area along arterial and major collector
streets. The developer shall note on the final plat and in the covenants and
restrictions for the development, all other public street landscaped buffer
areas which the development homeowners shall be required to maintain. Failure
to place such notes will not nullify the owners' responsibility as described in
this section. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.403: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
All public streets which form the perimeter of any residential or
nonresidential development, and all public streets within any residential or
nonresidential development where homes or buildings within the development will
not front on the streets, shall provide a minimum landscaped buffer area that
meets the requirements set forth in the cross sections of the transportation
master plan and the following:
   (1)   Uneven, creative landscaped buffer areas with varied setbacks and wall
heights are preferred.
   (2)   Stepped and staggered buffer walls shall not exceed forty foot (40')
increments of variation of height and setback.
   (3)   Serpentine sidewalks, which are encouraged, may be located within the
buffer area.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/d893e1fd2f01258397edc51c3aecb0cc2a58e863/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2894.gif]
(Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.404: GENERAL LANDSCAPING REQUIREMENTS:
   (1)   Landscaping, in accordance with the design guidelines, shall be
provided according to an approved plan. Landscaping may include berming,
contouring, rocks, boulders and drought tolerant desert vegetation.
   (2)   The developer shall note on the final plat or site plan, and in the
covenants and restrictions for the development, those public right of way
areas, including park strips, for which the homeowners shall have
responsibility for landscape improvements and maintenance. Failure to place
such notes will not nullify owners' responsibilities for park strips and
medians as described in this section. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 5. FENCING
15.05.501: PURPOSE:
Fencing may be used to provide privacy to property owners, buffer conflicting
uses, or to provide an architectural/design element to a development project.
Fencing is encouraged to be as low profile and open as possible to protect
scenic vistas from public streets and discourage separation from the community.
The materials, location, height and all elements of fencing shall comply with
the design guidelines. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.502: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
Permanent fencing shall be incorporated into the development design and
implemented by the developer in compliance with the design guidelines and shall
meet the following general requirements:
   (1)   All fencing designed and installed by the developer shall be approved
by the city and shall be considered part of the project improvements for
purposes of security and occupancy;
   (2)   All applicable zoning and building code requirements pertaining to
fencing shall be met; and
   (3)   All fencing installed by the developer shall be maintained in good
condition by the owners after the improvements guarantee is released, unless
said fencing is specifically accepted by the city for maintenance. (Ord. 2016-
02, 2016)
15.05.503: FENCING DESIGN:
The following design requirements pertaining to fencing shall be incorporated
into the development design and implemented by the developer in compliance with
the design guidelines. The developer shall install fencing at his/her expense
as follows:
   (1)   An approved fence between the development and any incompatible use
identified by the city, such as canals, ditches, flood channels or other
waterways or other hazardous or unsightly uses.
   (2)   An approved fence between the development and incompatible zones.
   (3)   An approved fence between public streets and rear and side yards of
single-family residential lots or parcels in agricultural and residential
zones.
   (4)   Concept drawings must be submitted to city staff for review prior to
construction.
   (5)   Building permits are required for fences or walls exceeding six feet
(6') in height.
   (6)   Fence height shall be measured from the natural grade to the top of
the fence or wall.
   (7)   Fence heights along public streets shall not exceed the maximum
heights shown in the chart that follows, except when natural lot elevation
would dictate a fence height too low to protect privacy. A five foot (5') fence
or wall may be built if the twelve foot (12') required buffer area is met.
   (8)   Fences and walls shall not exceed forty feet (40') of unbroken lengths
to reduce visual mass. Walls and fences that exceed forty feet (40') in length
shall be designed to vary in height and be stepped in an offset manner.
   (9)   When a fence or wall on a public street creates a continuous surface
greater than twenty feet (20') in length, it shall be softened visually with
acceptable vegetation.

From The Street Curb To The Fence)   (Measured From Grade Back
                                     Of Curb To The Top Of Fence)1

   Over 15 feet to 20 feet        6.5 feet
   Over 20 feet to 25 feet        7.0 feet
   Over 25 feet to 30 feet        7.5 feet
   Over 30 feet to 35 feet        8.0 feet
   Over 35 feet                   8.5 feet

be added to the top of any fence along the rear property boundaries for safety
purposes.

(Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 6. UTILITIES
15.05.601: GENERAL UTILITY REQUIREMENTS:
All utilities shall be designed in accordance with the City standard
specifications or for private franchised utilities shall be in conformance with
each utility's standards. Public utilities shall also be in conformance with
the general plan, master plans, capital facility plans, impact fee facility
plans, and City ordinances including City administrative rules and regulations
as approved by the City. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
   (1)   All utilities shall be provided through underground service in
properly recorded easements or rights-of-way.
      (a)   Existing overhead power lines adjacent to, and on the same side of
the street as, proposed development projects shall be relocated underground.
         (i)   Exceptions: Development projects in the Historic Township that
are not on a minor/major collector or arterial street; or the line voltage is
more than fifteen kilovolts (15 kV). (Ord. 2018-03, 2018)
   (2)   Underground utilities shall be installed only after the street has
been rough graded to a line and grade approved by the City.
   (3)   All utilities and other improvements that will be placed beneath the
asphalt pavement section shall be installed prior to the placement of any road
base and asphalt, and shall include any necessary crossing of other
improvements or utilities.
   (4)   All utilities shall extend through and/or to future connection points
for same, including the farthest point of the development for future growth, as
required by the City.
   (5)   The developer shall be responsible for the coordination of utility
installation with existing utilities, including the rerouting of existing
utilities.
   (6)   Right-of-way and easement dedications shall be provided in accordance
with City requirements and as necessary to provide all of the required
improvements listed above.
   (7)   Developers of subdivisions or condominiums, or any other development,
shall be required to design, construct and dedicate public improvements which
are necessary to serve the development and connect to existing and future
infrastructure.
   (8)   Impact and other fees and dedications associated with the development
are also required in addition to the construction and dedication of public
improvements required with the development. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.602: DRAWING OF RECORD:
Drawing of record, also known as as built drawings, are required for
developments that include the installation of public utilities. These drawings
shall be submitted in accordance with the requirements established by the City
standard specifications. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.603: RESPONSIBILITY FOR IMPROVEMENTS:
   (1)   Prior to final acceptance of public improvements by the City as
prescribed in this title, the developer shall be responsible for the proper
replacement, repair and maintenance of any public improvements associated with
the development which were installed by the developer. The developer shall be
obligated to the city to replace, repair and/or maintain any defective,
damaged, or deteriorating public improvements related to the development at
his/her expense until the time that said public improvements are inspected and
accepted by the city.
   (2)   In the event that certain areas or structures are provided within the
subdivision for private recreational use or as service facilities, the owner of
such land and buildings shall establish an arrangement to assure a continued
standard of maintenance consistent with the conditions of subdivision approval.
(Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 7. CONSTRUCTION
15.05.701: CONSTRUCTION OF IMPROVEMENTS:
No construction shall be started until the final plat and construction drawings
have been approved except as agreed by development agreement. The developer/
property owner may begin construction after:
   (1)   Final plat has been approved.
   (2)   Development agreement has been approved and recorded.
   (3)   Construction permit obtained from city including payment of fee.
   (4)   Restoration bond established with city.
   (5)   All necessary state and federal permits obtained.
   (6)   Preconstruction meeting held in accordance with standard
specifications. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.702: INSPECTIONS:
   (1)   Frequency: Construction work involving the installation of public
improvements in subdivisions and other developments shall be subject to the
inspection of the public works director and city engineer.
   (2)   Requests For Inspection: Requests for inspections shall be made to the
city engineer by the person responsible for the construction. Requests for
inspection on work shall be made one working day prior to the commencement of
the work. Inspections shall be made by the city engineer after various phases
of the construction work are completed. Any faulty or defective work shall be
corrected by the developer or the developer's contractor within a period of
thirty (30) days from the date of the city engineer's written notification to
the developer that correction of the faulty or defective work is required.
(Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.703: CONSTRUCTION FINAL COMPLETION:
The following items shall be provided prior to final completion of the project
and start of the warranty period:
   (1)   All required improvements have been installed and all punch list items
provided by the city have been satisfied.
   (2)   Final walk-through inspection has been completed by city.
   (3)   Final testing report submitted, reviewed and approved by the city.
   (4)   Record drawing has been submitted, reviewed and approved by the city.
   (5)   All disturbed areas have been stabilized and/or revegetated in
accordance with stormwater pollution prevention requirements.
   (6)   Warranty bond has been posted as security during the warranty period.
(Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.704: WARRANTY PERIOD:
   (1)   The warranty period shall commence on the date of final completion and
shall continue for one year thereafter for all improvements.
   (2)   If any deficiencies are found by the city during the warranty period
in materials or workmanship, the developer shall promptly resolve such defects
or deficiencies and request the city engineer to reinspect the improvements. If
the defective or deficient improvements are not corrected, the city will give
notice to the developer of the action to file on the security agreement for
completion of the improvements. If necessary the warranty period may be
extended until such deficiencies are corrected.
   (3)   At the end of the one year period, as applicable, the developer shall
request the city staff to make a final warranty period inspection of all
improvements. If the city engineer verifies that the improvements are
acceptable, the remaining warranty bond posted as security by the developer
under the security agreement shall be released. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.705: MAINTENANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS:
   (1)   Upon final completion of the project, the city will assume all
maintenance of public facilities with the exception of landscaping which shall
be maintained by the developer for the duration of the warranty period.
   (2)   In the event that certain areas or structures are provided within the
subdivision for private recreational use or as service facilities, the owner of
such land and buildings shall establish an arrangement to assure a continued
standard of maintenance consistent with the conditions of subdivision approval.
(Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 8. BONDING REQUIREMENTS FOR IMPROVEMENT GUARANTEE
15.05.801: IMPROVEMENT BOND:
In order to ensure proper completion and maintenance of required improvements
for a subdivision or condominium in the city, the developer or owner shall
provide an improvement bond of the type described below for completion with the
city to install improvements to city standards.
   (1)   Types Of Improvement Bonds Allowed:
      (a)   The developer/property owner shall either provide a cash bond
deposited with the city, an irrevocable letter of credit, or an escrow security
agreement with a financial institution where the full cash amount is held in a
separate escrow account as security for the city, for the improvements on the
final plat or site plan as directed by the city manager, city engineer or city
attorney. A surety bond is not an allowed type of improvement bond. The
improvement bond shall be posted prior to the city attorney's signing of the
final plat or site plan, and prior to recording of any accompanying documents.
A description of the required improvement bond shall be included in the
recorded development agreement.
      (b)   The cash bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or escrow security
agreement shall ensure the timely and satisfactory construction of all required
public improvements, private streets and sidewalks, perimeter walls, and
landscaped buffer areas and provide a guarantee for said improvements. The city
engineer shall determine the amount of the improvement guarantee, which shall
be one hundred ten percent (110%) of the estimated cost of the improvements.
The improvement guarantee may be reduced at intervals at the request of the
developer/owner as improvements are installed as specified in the city
engineer's estimated cost of the improvements to be installed down to the
amount of the required warranty bond plus five percent (5%) until final
acceptance by the city engineer following the warranty period.
      (c)   For required street improvements on unimproved public streets not
yet ready to have such improvements installed, a cash bond in the amount of one
hundred percent (100%) of the estimated required street improvements shall be
obtained. The cash bond shall be in the form of cash deposited with Ivins City
for the future construction by the city of the required street improvements.
The city shall bear the risk of any increased future costs of installing the
required improvements. If the city has not commenced the installation of the
required improvements for which a cash bond has been deposited with the city
within ten (10) years from the posting of the cash bond, the city shall refund
the cash bond, without interest thereon, to the developer/property owner who
deposited the cash bond with the city.
   (2)   Installation Of Improvements: The developer/property owner may install
improvements after approval of the final plat and recording of the development
agreement in lieu of bonding for required improvements. All improvements shall
be completed in accordance with approved construction drawings as required by
this title and shall be approved by the city engineer prior to the recording of
the final plat. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.802: RESTORATION BOND:
A restoration bond equal to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per disturbed acre
for the project or phase of the project being constructed with a minimum of two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). This bond shall be posted in cash to
the city prior to construction of any improvements in accordance with the
recorded development agreement. This restoration bond is intended to protect
the city from unfinished improvements that may create safety hazards or
nuisance and debris problems. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.803: WARRANTY BOND:
   (1)   The amount of the warranty bond shall be ten percent (10%) of the
lesser of the:
      (a)   City engineer's original estimated cost of completion; or
      (b)   Developer/property owner's reasonable proven cost of completion.
   (2)   The warranty bond types are limited to the same types allowed for the
improvement bond. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
PART 9. BUILDING PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY
15.05.901: BUILDING PERMITS:
   (1)   Building permits may be issued for model homes and other on site
amenities if:
      (a)   The final plat has been approved by the city council, planning
commission, all affected government agencies, city departments and public
utilities; and
      (b)   Satisfactory security guarantees for completion of public
improvements have been submitted and approved or improvements have been
installed or are being installed in accordance with the recorded development
agreement.
   (2)   No other building permits will be issued, and the developer may not
begin construction on any off site or on site improvements or on any building
structure, until:
      (a)   The development agreement has been recorded and the final plat is
approved (and recorded if improvements are bonded) and the developer/property
owner and all approvals of the city council, planning commission, all affected
government agencies, city departments and public utilities have been given. The
development agreement shall contain satisfactory security guarantees for
installation of public improvements or provisions for the completion of
improvements.
      (b)   Water, sewer, storm drain and all other public utilities are
provided to the subject lot or parcel and have been approved and accepted by
the city and affected government agencies and public utilities.
      (c)   All public streets required for and contained in the development
have been improved with curb, gutter and road base placed, graded, compacted
and approved on entire road surface. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
15.05.902: CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY:
It shall be unlawful for any developer or owner to sell any portion of an
approved development without informing the prospective buyer or builder that
occupancy may not be obtained until all permanent improvements are installed
and approved by the city. A certificate of occupancy may be issued upon
compliance with the following:
   (1)   All water, sewer, storm drain and all other public utilities are
provided to the subject lot or parcel and are approved and accepted by the city
and affected government agencies and public utilities;
   (2)   All public streets required for, and contained in, the development
have been improved with curb, gutter, sidewalk and paving according to city
standards;
   (3)   All improvements and requirements for the development, including, but
not limited to, fire protection, storm drainage, lighting and fencing have been
installed and approved according to city standards;
   (4)   All conditions and requirements of approval are satisfied, including
recording of plats, dedication of property and recording of agreements or
easements; and
   (5)   If any improvements have not been installed because of weather or
otherwise, a security agreement for the delayed improvements must be in place
with the city as required by section
15.05.801 of this chapter. (Ord. 2016-02, 2016)
CHAPTER 6
PHASED SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
Part 1. General Provisions
15.06.101: General
15.06.102: Purpose And Intent
Part 2. Phased Subdivision Master Plan
15.06.201: Application
15.06.202: Review Process
15.06.203: Standards For Review
15.06.204: Termination Of Approval
15.06.205: Preliminary Plan And Final Plat Required
15.06.206: Dedication Of Open Space Required
15.06.207: Development Agreements
15.06.208: Recordation Of Phased Subdivision Master Plan And Development
Agreement
PART 1. GENERAL PROVISIONS
15.06.101: GENERAL:
Conventional subdivisions may be completed in phases. Prior to the application
and approval of a preliminary plan and final plat, as required in chapter 4 of
this title, a developer/property owner may submit a phased subdivision master
plan that will encompass the general development parameters for the entire
subdivision. The phased subdivision master plan will establish phases, proposed
uses and general development guidelines for all phases of the subdivision. The
established uses, development parameters and guidelines shall be included in a
development agreement as required in chapter 4 of this title. (Ord. 2006-02,
2006)
15.06.102: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose and intent of the phased subdivision master plan is to allow a
conceptual review and approval of general development parameters prior to
detailed reviews of a subdivision preliminary plan and final plat. The phased
subdivision master plan is intended to establish uses, phases and general
development guidelines for all phases of a phased subdivision. It is the intent
of this process to allow a developer and the city to master plan large scale,
multi- phased developments and proceed with the development approval, as well
as the actual construction, on a phased basis over a period of years. After
approval of the phased subdivision master plan, a preliminary plan and final
plat (as required in chapter 4 of this title) must be approved prior to
development of the subdivision. Required improvements are outlined in chapter 5
of this title. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
PART 2. PHASED SUBDIVISION MASTER PLAN
15.06.201: APPLICATION:
A phased subdivision master plan application shall be submitted, along with
applicable fees, and contain the following:
   (1)   Legal description of property and indication of gross area.
   (2)   Nature of the applicant's interest in the land to be developed.
   (3)   All persons owning or having interest in land proposed for
development, including easements, tenants, licenses, lien holders or other
interests.
   (4)   A generalized location map showing surrounding land use, zoning and
traffic circulation.
   (5)   An analysis of the existing site conditions which includes:
      (a)   Topographic contours with intervals of no more than two feet (2'),
to a distance of one hundred feet (100') beyond the property boundary;
      (b)   Location and extent of major vegetative cover (if any);
      (c)   Location and extent of perennial or intermittent streams or water
ponding areas;
      (d)   Existing drainage and irrigation flows and patterns;
      (e)   Natural features such as rock formations; and
      (f)   Other information that may be relevant to the property.
   (6)   Open space expressed as percentage of total area, as well as in acres.
   (7)   A land use plan at a scale not smaller than one inch equals one
hundred feet (1" = 100'), equivalent zoning categories, all arterial and
collector street circulation elements, pedestrian and/or bicycle circulation,
open spaces and recreational areas.
   (8)   Plans indicating the approximate alignment and sizing of water lines,
sanitary sewers and storm drains, surface drainage, as well as easements for
all utilities, if necessary.
   (9)   Conceptual landscaping plans in accordance with the design guidelines.
   (10)   A traffic analysis report, if deemed necessary by the city and/or
required by the city transportation master plan.
   (11)   Phasing plan indicating the areas to be phased and the sequence of
future development. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.06.202: REVIEW PROCESS:
   (1)   Staff Review And Report: The phased subdivision master plan
application will be reviewed by the zoning administrator for general compliance
with this title, the standard specifications for design and construction,
design guidelines and all applicable ordinances. If the application is not
complete or not in general compliance, the zoning administrator shall notify
the applicant in writing and specify the deficiencies in the application. When
the application is complete and in general compliance, the zoning administrator
shall forward the completed application to the technical review committee,
other city staff and departments, utility board, and affected government
entities and public utilities to obtain comment regarding the application. City
staff and the utility board will review the phased subdivision master plan,
make site visits, discuss engineering issues, check compliance with the general
plan and city ordinances to determine the adequacy of public facilities. The
zoning administrator shall prepare a staff report which shall include all
review comments by the technical review committee, city departments and all
other agencies required to review the application and submittals. The zoning
administrator shall forward the completed application and the staff report to
the planning commission.
   (2)   Planning Commission Public Hearing: Once all application requirements
have been met and the staff report completed, the application will be scheduled
on the planning commission agenda for a public hearing. Notice of the public
hearing shall be sent to all property owners of record in the Washington County
recorder's office within three hundred feet (300') of the property line of the
proposed subdivision. Notice shall also be published in a newspaper of general
circulation at least ten (10) days prior to the public hearing. The planning
commission shall receive public comment at the public hearing regarding the
proposed phased subdivision master plan.
   (3)   Planning Commission Review: If the planning commission finds that the
proposed plan complies with the requirements of this title, finds that there
are adequate public utilities and services to support the proposed development,
and is satisfied with the preliminary plan of the subdivision, it shall approve
the plan, or approve the plan with conditions. If the planning commission finds
that the proposed plan does not meet the requirements of this title or other
applicable ordinances, it shall deny such plan.
   (4)   City Council Review: Once the planning commission has approved the
phased subdivision master plan, the application will be scheduled on the city
council meeting agenda. If the city council finds that the proposed plan
complies with the requirements of this chapter, finds that there are adequate
public utilities and services to support the proposed development, and is
satisfied with the preliminary plan of the subdivision, it shall approve the
plan, or approve the plan with conditions. If the city council finds that the
proposed plan does not meet the requirements of this title or other applicable
ordinances, it shall deny such plan. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.06.203: STANDARDS FOR REVIEW:
   (1)   The proposed subdivision shall conform to the general plan, zoning
ordinance, this title, design guidelines, standard specifications and any other
applicable ordinances.
   (2)   The proposed water source shall have adequate capacity and a method of
distribution within the subdivision. If applicable, an agreement to provide
water from the water provider and/or evidence of availability of water may be
required.
   (3)   The proposed sewage system must meet state and city standards and
regulations.
   (4)   The proposed methods for fire protection must comply with this title
and other city regulations.
   (5)   The proposed uses for the property must be appropriate to the zoning
district.
   (6)   The layout/design must be responsive to the constraints of topography,
soil types, watercourses, floodplains, visual impacts and preservation of
views.
   (7)   Adequate public services must be available to meet the needs of the
proposed subdivision, including roads, gas, electric, telephone, mail, police
and fire protection, schools and recreation. If, after reviewing the
application, making site visits and examining materials submitted by the
developers, the city staff and the utility board determine that adequate public
improvements are not available and will not be available by the time of final
plat approval, then one of the following alternatives may be elected, at the
discretion of the city council, to assure that adequate public services are
available at the time of occupancy:
      (a)   Allow the developer to voluntarily construct those public
improvements which are necessary to service development, as determined by city
staff and utility board, by entering into an appropriate form of development
agreement which shall include, if applicable, provisions to recoup any expenses
incurred above and beyond those reasonable and necessary for, or related to,
the need created by, or the benefit conferred upon, the proposed development,
and the method and conditions upon which expenses may be recouped. Any
agreement authorized by this subsection must be executed prior to the
construction of the improvements and in compliance with the development
agreement requirements of this title;
      (b)   Require the timing, sequencing and phasing of the proposed
development consistent with the availability of adequate public improvements;
      (c)   Defer preliminary plan and final plat approval and the issuance of
building permits until all necessary public improvements are adequate and
available; or
      (d)   Deny the master plan approval and allow the applicant to reapply
when adequate public improvements are available.
   (8)   The planning commission and city council may request additional
information and/or provide comments, directions and suggestions to the
applicant. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.06.204: TERMINATION OF APPROVAL:
Failure to submit a preliminary plan on the first phase, as approved in the
phased subdivision master plan and development agreement, within one year of
the approval of the phased subdivision master plan shall terminate all
proceedings and render the phased subdivision master plan null and void. (Ord.
2006-02, 2006)
15.06.205: PRELIMINARY PLAN AND FINAL PLAT REQUIRED:
A preliminary plan and final plat application must (as outlined in chapter 4 of
this title) be approved prior to the development of the subdivision. (Ord.
2006-02, 2006)
15.06.206: DEDICATION OF OPEN SPACE REQUIRED:
All open space, including lands designated as trails, easements, buffers,
parks, medians, and any other open space, shall be deeded as part of the phased
subdivision master plan development agreement. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
15.06.207: DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENTS:
Requirements for subdivision development agreements are set forth in Title 16,
Chapter 9 of the Ivins City Code. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006; amd. Ord. 2023-11, 2023)
15.06.208: RECORDATION OF PHASED SUBDIVISION MASTER PLAN AND DEVELOPMENT
AGREEMENT:
The approved phased subdivision master plan and development agreement shall be
recorded, and shall be included in the subdivision plat records of the
Washington County recorder's office. Recordation by the city shall only take
place after all of the necessary signatures are obtained, all approvals given,
and all applicable bonds and fees have been posted with the zoning
administrator. (Ord. 2006-02, 2006)
TITLE 16
ZONING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
TITLE, PURPOSE, DECLARATION OF INTENT AND EFFECTIVE DATE
SECTION:
16.01.101: Short Title
16.01.102: Authority
16.01.103: Declaration
16.01.104: Purpose
16.01.105: Applicability
16.01.106: Conflict
16.01.107: Permits And Licenses To Conform
16.01.108: Effective Date
16.01.109: Omissions Not Waiver
16.01.110: Repealer And Effect
16.01.101: SHORT TITLE:
This title shall be known as the IVINS CITY ZONING ORDINANCE (hereinafter
"ordinance", "the ordinance", "this ordinance", "zoning ordinance", "Ivins
zoning ordinance", "this title" or "land use ordinance"). This title shall be
codified as title 16 of the Ivins City Municipal Code (hereinafter "this
Code"). (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.01.102: AUTHORITY:
The City Council adopts this title pursuant to the Municipal Land Use,
Development and Management Act, as provided by Utah Code Annotated title 10,
chapter 9a, as amended (hereinafter "the Act") and all other authorities and
provisions of State and Federal statutory and common law, as applicable. This
title is a land use ordinance, as authorized and identified by the Act. (Ord.
2005-13, 2005)
16.01.103: DECLARATION:
This title provides for the establishment of zoning districts, with associated
land use requirements and standards, for the guidance, management and
regulation of land uses, buildings and structures, and other related activities
occurring within the Municipal boundaries of the City. This title shall be
interpreted to be consistent with, and to meet all requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.01.104: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this title shall conform to the purposes stated in the Act, as
amended, namely: to provide for the health, safety, and welfare, and promote
the prosperity, improve the morals, peace and good order, comfort, convenience,
and aesthetics of the City and its present and future inhabitants and
businesses, to protect the tax base, to secure economy in governmental
expenditures, to foster the State's agricultural and other industries, to
protect both urban and nonurban development, to protect and ensure access to
sunlight for solar energy devices, to provide fundamental fairness in land use
regulation, and to protect property values. (Ord. 2017-06, 2017)
16.01.105: APPLICABILITY:
   (1)   Applications determined complete shall be processed, reviewed and
approved or denied, subject to the provisions of this title, and all amendments
thereto, and all other applicable ordinances of the City, in effect at the time
the application is determined to be complete by the Zoning Administrator, as
required by chapter 13 of this title.
   (2)   No building or structure shall be erected, and no existing building or
structure shall be moved, altered or enlarged, nor shall any land, building or
premises be used, designed for, or intended to be used for, any purpose or in
any manner other than as allowed by this title.
   (3)   This title shall apply to all lands located within the Municipal
boundaries of the City, unless exempted by this title or other lawful
exemption.
   (4)   This title shall be held to be the minimum requirements necessary to
protect the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City, and
achieve the purposes of this title. (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.01.106: CONFLICT:
This title shall not nullify any laws, ordinances or requirements that are more
restrictive, but shall prevail over any laws, ordinances or requirements that
are less restrictive. (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.01.107: PERMITS AND LICENSES TO CONFORM:
All Land Use Authorities, as identified herein, with the authority to issue
approvals, permits or licenses required by this title, shall require that such
approvals, permits or licenses conform to the provisions of this title and
shall not issue any approvals, permits or licenses for uses, buildings or
structures for any purpose in conflict with the provisions of this title. (Ord.
2017-06, 2017)
16.01.108: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This title was adopted by ordinance 2005-13, following its passage by the City
Council on June 2, 2005. As provided by the terms of ordinance 2005-13, this
title shall take effect on July 1, 2005. (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.01.109: OMISSIONS NOT WAIVER:
An omission to specify or enumerate in this title those provisions of general
law applicable to all Utah cities shall not be construed to be a waiver of the
benefits of any such provisions. (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.01.110: REPEALER AND EFFECT:
Upon its adoption by the City Council and upon its effective date, this title
shall repeal all provisions of the City zoning ordinance existing on the
effective date hereof, and shall henceforth govern and control the use of all
lands lying within the Municipal boundaries of the City.
This title shall be construed to carry out the purposes set forth herein, and
the Act, and to avoid conflict with the laws of the United States of America,
the State of Utah, or any other limitations imposed by law. If any chapter,
section, subsection, provision, sentence or clause of this title is declared
invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such
determination shall not impair the validity of the remainder of this title,
which shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
CHAPTER 2
INTERPRETATION OF REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
16.02.101: Interpretation
16.02.102: Administrative Interpretations
16.02.103: Rules For Interpretation Of Zoning District Boundaries
16.02.101: INTERPRETATION:
In interpreting and applying this title, the requirements contained herein are
declared the minimum requirements for the purposes set forth in this title and
the act. The provisions of this title shall be:
   (1)   Liberally construed in favor of the city.
   (2)   Deemed to neither limit nor repeal any other powers granted by the
act, or any other state or federal statutes.
   (3)   Applied and interpreted as follows, except where the context clearly
requires otherwise:
      (a)   The words "shall" and "must" are mandatory. The words "should" and
"may" are permissive.
      (b)   Words used or defined in one tense or form shall include other
tenses or derivative forms.
      (c)   Words used in the singular shall include the plural; words used in
the plural shall include the singular.
      (d)   Words referencing a gender shall extend and be applied to the other
gender and shall be considered gender neutral.
      (e)   In the event of a conflict between the text of this title and any
maps, illustrations, captions, figures or other material, the text of this
title shall apply and control.
      (f)   The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specified
examples, but is intended to provide guidance and to be illustrative only.
      (g)   The word "and" indicates that all connected items, conditions,
provisions or events shall apply.
      (h)   The word "or" indicates that one or more of the connected items,
conditions, provisions or events shall apply.
      (i)   The words "either or" indicate that the connected terms,
conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly, but not in combination.
(Ord. 2005-13, 2005)
16.02.102: ADMINISTRATIVE INTERPRETATIONS:
   (1)   Purpose: To promote day to day efficiencies in the administration and
implementation of this title, and where ambiguity, conflicting provisions or
confusion may exist in any provision or requirement of this title, this section
is provided to allow and authorize the city attorney to make interpretations of
this title, as needed, guided by the purposes set forth herein and applied to a
specific circumstance.
   (2)   Authority: The city attorney is authorized to render interpretations
of the text of this title.
   (3)   Initiation: Any person may request an administrative interpretation of
any text provision of this title by presenting an application for an
administrative interpretation.
   (4)   Procedure: An application for an administrative interpretation shall
be considered and processed as provided in this chapter:
      (a)   A complete application shall be submitted to the zoning
administrator.
      (b)   After an application is determined to be complete, the city
attorney shall review the application and make an interpretation in accordance
with the standards set forth in this chapter.
      (c)   After making a decision, the city attorney shall provide a written
copy of the administrative interpretation to the applicant. A written copy of
the administrative interpretation of the city attorney shall also be maintained
in the office of the city recorder.
   (5)   Standards For Making Administrative Interpretations: The city attorney
shall apply the following standards in making an administrative interpretation:
      (a)   The administrative interpretation shall not have the effect of
adding or removing any provision of this title.
      (b)   The city attorney shall not make any interpretation on the location
of any zoning district boundary, such interpretations being provided by section
16.02.103 of this chapter.
      (c)   An administrative interpretation shall be consistent with the
purposes of this title and any previously rendered administrative
interpretations, based on similar facts.
      (d)   An administrative interpretation concerning a use interpretation
shall not allow the establishment of a use that is substantially different or
allow any prohibited use in the zoning district.
      (e)   No use interpretation shall permit the establishment of any use
that would be inconsistent with the purposes of the zoning district in which it
would be located.
   (6)   Effect Of Interpretation: An administrative interpretation shall only
apply to the property for which an interpretation is given. An interpretation
finding a use to be a class I, class II, class III, class IV or class V use
shall not authorize the establishment of the use but may authorize the filing
of land use applications necessary for any approvals, permits or licenses, as
may be required.
   (7)   Appeal: Any person adversely affected by an interpretation of any text
provision of this title, rendered by the city attorney, may appeal that
interpretation by filing a written appeal as provided in chapter 30 of this
title.
(Ord. 2005-13, 2005; amd. Ord. 2016-06, 2016; Ord. 2024-11, 2024)
16.02.103: RULES FOR INTERPRETATION OF ZONING DISTRICT BOUNDARIES:
In the event of the need to determine the location of the boundary of a zoning
district, the commission shall have the authority and jurisdiction to render a
written determination of the boundary of a zoning district. The commission
shall take into consideration the following criteria in rendering such
determination:
   (1)   The policies and development standards pertaining to such zoning
district.
   (2)   In areas divided into lots, a zoning district boundary shall follow
the boundary of a lot, unless clearly intended to divide a lot for reasons of
topography, landform or other natural or manmade feature.
   (3)   In areas not subdivided into lots, wherever a zoning district is
indicated as a strip adjacent to and paralleling a right of way, the depth of
such strips shall be in accordance with dimensions measured at right angles
from the centerline of the right of way, and the length of frontage shall be in
accordance with dimensions measured from section, quarter section or division
lines, or centerlines of rights of way, unless otherwise indicated.
   (4)   Where a zoning district boundary follows a creek, stream, watercourse,
drainage channel, floodway or other natural or manmade feature, such boundary
shall be deemed to be the centerline of such creek, stream, watercourse,
drainage channel, floodway or other natural or manmade feature, unless clearly
intended to do otherwise.
   (5)   Where a zoning district boundary follows the right of way of any road,
street, trail or other public or private right of way or easement, such
boundary shall be deemed to be the centerline of such road, street, trail or
other public or private right of way or easement, unless clearly intended to do
otherwise. (Ord. 2005-13, 2005)

LAND USE AUTHORITIES AND DECISION MAKING
SECTION:
16.03.101: Land Use Authorities Provided
